DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION AMENDMENT (TRIBUNAL'S POWERS) BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Vigor) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 so as to clarify the powers of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to determine the conditions to be observed by licensees under the Act.
Bill presented by Senator Vigor, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have my second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This week's events in the High Court force me to make a few brief explanatory remarks. Honourable senators will be aware that on Tuesday, the High Court held that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's power over standards did not extend to examining programmes before they are screened.

The case started at 10.22 on Tuesday morning, there was a short adjournment at 12.33 and eighteen minutes later the Court returned to give reasons for judgment. We should be grateful for the opportunity to study the High Court's decision and to devise temporary wording that will tide our film and television production industries over until the government is able to present a long-term solution. We now have excellent drama programmes coming on-stream in the children's television area.
They are attracting a lot of world-wide interest. Our best writers directors and producers have become involved in this area.

Now, for some months there will be no steadying influence in the industry unless this Bill-or something very similar-is passed. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will not be able to examine material before it is screened. The production industry will not know where it stands.
Creative people will move to other areas of film and television work, many of them perhaps never to return, because their confidence has been shaken.
If I may quote Mrs Hazel Hawke, a director on the board of the Australian Children's Television Foundation, on children's television:

''Failure to achieve satisfactory results has been due to the absence of concentrated and continued action and commitment not only by the networks and advertisers, but by the regulators, by governments, by film-funding bodies and the industry itself.''

Unless we act now, we will add another chapter in that discontinuity, I have great faith in the Minister's commitment to developing a long-term broadcasting strategy that gives all Australians real diversity of programme material.

I support the changes being sought in the Minister's Bills before this Parliament. I do believe that the situation which has been clarified this week calls for remedial action right away, both in the children's television and Australian advertising content areas.

What I am bringing forward should avoid dislocation if the Saatchi case is determined on the same principles as this one. I ask the Senate to support our creative talent in this country, and to offer immediate protection for our children.

It has long been known to specialists in communications law that the wording in several parts of the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 would not stand up very well to close inspection by the courts. One of the sources of such speculation has been the haphazard way in which the process of amendment has been attended to over the years. With changes or solutions often having been made on the run, there has not always been the time to ensure that new sections or amendments are in reasonable harmony with what is already there. While no-one raises objections, the difficulty remains hypothetical and presumably does not receive priority in corrective attention. This is the situation in relation to the words 'standards' and 'conditions' that appear somewhat randomly in sections 16, 99 and 100 of the principal Act.

In both the Herald-Sun case which was determined by the High Court earlier this week, and the Saatchi case which is still on appeal, the power of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to set quantitative standards relating to Australian content, or enforce such standards through pre-classification of programmes, has been thrown into doubt by the courts' decision that a precise and narrow meaning must be adopted in construing the very word ''standards''. For instance, it is a requirement of Paragraph 39 of the Tribunal's Television Program Standards that all televised advertisements be produced in Australia or New Zealand. In general, they may exceed 20 per cent of matter filmed overseas only if the work is carried out by an Australian production crew or that material is archival or relates to the promotion of films, recordings or entertainers from overseas. Last November, His Honour Justice Beaumont ruled that advertising standards could only deal with quality, saying, ''It is one thing to prescribe a minimum quality for a product. It is a different thing to restrict the location of its production.''

The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has appealed against that decision, and an outcome is still awaited. If it is held that standards can only be qualitative, without a change in the current legislation, there will be nothing to stop an avalanche of overseas-produced advertisements being brought into this country. Because the advertising and film production industries are closely related, the removal of opportunities to gain technical skills and to develop creative talent locally would lead to sharp declines in our output in both fields. If we replace the word ''standards'' with the word ''conditions'' which has a much broader meaning, as an examination of the Oxford English Dictionary confirms, we should find the Tribunals powers in the area of advertising sufficiently buttressed, and consequently encourage an industry which is able to attain the technical excellence that sees participants regularly win international awards. The same alteration in those other sections where ''standards'' are currently referred to should strengthen the Tribunal's case if further litigation arises. However, the question of pre-classification might not be advanced by this word-change alone, as the power to require the submission of programmes for examination before screening might be taken to be distinct from any power to impose ''conditions''. The High Court has already said that being able to set ''standards'' is quite different from being able to determine in advance whether or not a particular programme meets those standards. It would be quite consistent to adopt the same approach even with ''conditions''. In the case of children's television, past experience has shown that unless licences are required, by something more than public expectation or moral obligation, to screen high-quality productions, they will not devote too much money or effort in catering for younger audiences. According to Mrs Hawke's speech when opening this month's three-day conference, ''The Challenge of Kids' Television'', held in Melbourne, even with the previously perceived standards in operation, licensees were spending only about 6 per cent of their budgets on Australian children's programmes. Yet there are 4.6 million Australians aged 16 years or younger, most of whom will watch more television than they will have formal education. As Mrs Hawke said of this nation's future leaders at that conference, ''Their major source of entertainment is television and most of their free time is spent in front of a television set. The tragedy is that it does so little good when it could do so much''.

Everyone who works in the area will acknowledge that without the ''C'' classification system, we would not have got nearly as far as we have. The addition of a drama component-8 hours of first-release Australian children's drama in each year-to be screened by each licensee has led to the nation's best writers, directors and producers, people such as Bob Ellis, Karl Schultz, Paul Cox and Jan Sardi, becoming involved in exciting new projects. Quite a large number of top-notch children's programmes are nearing the final stages of production. Some of them are already attracting interest in other parts of the world, and it may prove possible to re-evaluate viability in this area if substantial sales are clinched. The very real progress that is represented by the Winners series, The Henderson Kids, I Own The Racecourse, and The Fire in The Stone, commissioned by both national and commercial telecasters alike must not be frittered away by decisions that bring uncertainty and frighten away investors and talented industry professionals. We cannot afford to leave this area unattended even for a few short months, just as the fruits of many years' hard work by dedicated people are becoming apparent.

I have been influenced by the desperate need to preserve continuity and show a proper regard for our children to draft a clause that will specifically enable the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to inspect children's programmes before they go to air, and to bring in this Bill right now. On 30 April when he spoke at the National Press Club, the Minister for Communications reiterated the benefits that accrue to licensees from a controlled market-place and the obligations that they have to the community in return for their monopoly of the broadcasting spectrum. I am of the opinion that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has continued to steer a course in the public interest to the extent that the Act which binds it has permitted, even in the absence of a statement of the general principle or objectives of our broadcasting system, and with the interruption of a variety of curious amendments arrived at without reference to long-term goals. Consequently, I have specifically excluded only the news and current affairs area from the theoretical ambit of my interim reassertion of the Tribunal's powers. If the truth be known, the Tribunal and its staff are flat out trying to cope with the current plethora of enquiries, and have had to postpone full examination of the Australian content question and that concerning the status of woman in the electronic media. The Tribunal really doesn't have the resources to monitor compliance with what were perceived to be standards within its power to determine, let alone contemplate widening its sphere of influence. I am sure that what I have put forward will really only let it ''hold the fort'' in the public interest until such time, not too far distant, as the government has had the opportunity to consider and introduce standard-setting and monitoring powers which will serve the Australian film and television industry and the Australian public well for many years thereafter.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendments made by the Senate to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: DAIRY PRODUCE MARKET SUPPORT LEVY BILL 1985DAIRY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985DAIRY PRODUCE MARKET SUPPORT BILL 1985DAIRY INDUSTRY STABILIZATION LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night the Senate was debating the Dairy Produce Market Support Levy Bill 1985, the Dairy Legislation Amendment Bill 1985, the Dairy Produce Market Support Bill 1985 and the Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy Amendment Bill 1985. This package of Bills is designed to establish new marketing arrangements for the Australian dairy industry. As the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has pointed out, the Australian dairy industry is once again facing serious financial crisis. While all States are undoubtedly affected by this crisis, Victoria and Tasmania, which produce a higher percentage of milk for manufacturing purposes, are obviously the worst hit. Victoria produces nearly 60 per cent of Australia's total milk production, of which slightly less than 90 per cent goes into manufactured products. Most of these products are exported. This is where the first problem arises.

SPEECH.PARA: The outlook for the dairy industry is due to a range of reasons, such as depressed prices, rising costs and declining incomes of the people in the industry. As has been noted in the debates in the Senate with regard to other rural industries, the source of many of our problems is the domination in world trade of the major manufacturing dairy organisations of the European Economic Community. The low prices currently prevailing are largely a result of the policies of the EEC and of the United States of America. These policies have been responsible for generating massive stockpiles of dairy products and, as the Industries Assistance Commission report noted in 1983, the combined EEC and United States stocks are nearly 80 times Australia's total annual butter production.

Given that situation, the dairy industry is faced with enormous difficulties and enormous problems. The end result of the increased support in the EEC has been a drop in prices. In fact, they are the lowest since 1977. The short term outlook at the international level is a likely increase in the consumption of manufactured dairy products in the major producing countries. Possibly there will be some lowering of production and some decline in the level of international dairy stocks, but any reduction is likely to be marginal, given that the stocks are at the moment at record high levels. Any recovery in the import demand for dairy products is less certain and there is very little prospect of an improvement in the international dairy market during this year and possibly even next year.

I turn to Australia's domestic situation. It can be argued that the current marketing arrangements have actually contributed to the problem. Artificial factors introduced by governments have encouraged milk output beyond that required for the profitable market outlets. Dairy farmers have received misleading market signals because of the manner in which domestic prices have been set and the character of the price equalisation arrangements. In fact, Australia's dairy output in the three years to 1983-84 rose by 14 per cent and stocks of dairy products in Australia now comprise about 20 to 22 per cent of production.

If the current arrangements were maintained the low prices on world markets would ensure that unit returns for manufactured milk would remain depressed and there would be further contraction in dairy farm numbers, particularly in Victoria and Tasmania. One fairly obvious way to address these problems is to reduce the incentives to dairy farmers to continue producing excessive amounts of milk. Put simply, there are two ways of doing this. One is through a quota arrangement and the other is by exposing farmers to price signals which parallel national and international market situations. Earlier this year the Australian Dairy Industry Conference had proposed a plan adopting the former approach, while the Government is now proposing a plan which essentially adopts the latter approach. In certain respects industry representatives and the Government agree about the objectives of the exercise. The disagreement has been about the means to achieve those objectives. It is known that the ADIC plan was accepted by the industry, accepted by the States and accepted initially by the Government. However, it was finally rejected at Cabinet level.

The features of the new plan that the Government has put forward address the problems which are essentially confronting the manufacturing sector. Market milk has long been the responsibility of State governments and there are two broad classes of dairy farmers-those with access to the lucrative market milk sector and those who supply the manufacturing sector where returns are much more adversely affected by the international trends than those of the sector which grows and sells on the domestic market.

The Government has stated that its aim is to lead to a more truly national dairy industry and to develop a more efficient and profitable industry, able to respond as quickly as possible to changing market conditions and technology. The industry, while objecting to certain provisions in these Bills, has clearly accepted the thrust of the Government's plan. It is vitally important that that be acknowledged. The industry has, I believe, moved as far as possible to accommodate this plan. It is not easy and the task has been one of bringing together a range of disparate ideas, needs and industries. At the national level the industry has achieved this and the time is now right for an accommodation between the market and the industry. I believe that the industry has set the groundwork for that by really moving a very long way to accommodate itself to a plan which initially it regarded as the second best option and an option which was much further down the track than it would have liked to have gone. Hence the industry itself has put forward a range of proposals-four in number-which concern not the plan but the implementation of the plan. These amendments that the industry has proposed to the Bills are certainly not designed to thwart the intention of the plan but merely to ameliorate some of its harsher provisions.

I now turn to the individual Bills which make up this package. The first of these, the Dairy Produce Market Support Bill, contains many of the essential features of the new marketing arrangements. Under these arrangements, market support payments would be used to increase export returns to an export target figure, thereby providing, as does the existing arrangement, a measure of domestic price support. The dairy industry believes that export market support payments should be determined by the Australian Dairy Corporation by relating the subsidy to the milk content of the exported products. The Opposition has foreshadowed an amendment to be moved in the Committee stage to this effect. The Australian Democrats will support it.

I believe that the Government's proposal is open to fair criticism. First, relating the export subsidy for individual products to a three-year moving average of export returns could lead to erroneous calculations. One of the three years, for example, is a forward estimate and hence could be quite wrong. Secondly, the proposed system would not maximise the farm gate return from the volume of milk the industry has available to export. Thirdly, the system provides excessively high support for whole milk powder and, we believe, could lead to serious anomalies. To illustrate that, if we look at $1 per tonne return for butter, skim milk, cheese, casein and whole milk and translate it into farm gate returns under the Government's plan and the approach adopted by the industry which is incorporated in the Opposition's amendment, it can be seen that there is very little difference between the two in regard to any of the products other than whole milk powder. The amendment proposed by the Opposition would remove the anomaly which is contained in the legislation. I note in passing that, although the proposed amendments would seem to give too much power to the industry, it has to be remembered that, after all, the industry is paying the subsidy and not the taxpayer.

The Dairy Legislation Amendment Bill 1985 contains amendments to the Dairy Produce Act 1924 and the Dairy Produce Sales Promotion Act 1958. The most significant provision is that which discontinues export pooling for production on or after 1 July this year. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has pointed to the problems he sees arising from export pooling. But I believe that the dairy industry has argued cogently that the abolition of export pooling from essentially the end of next month, would cause severe discontinuities and probably would lead to severe disruption. There would be unnecessary price competition between exporters on some of the more lucrative export markets. Opening prices in 1985-86 would fall by about $1 per kilogram because, without an export pool, the Dairy Corporation would be unable to provide initial advances to manufacturers at the level at which they have done to date. Again, the Opposition will move an amendment and the Australian Democrats will support it.

Honourable senators should note that the industry position does not argue in favour of indefinite export pooling. The proposal is that export pools on butter and cheese should be continued in 1985-86 and 1986-87. The industry believes that the loss of export pooling can be accommodated in 1987-88. Indeed, the amendment has a sunset clause built in it. This Parliament would be required to undertake no further action and export pooling would cease at that time. Under the current system, the winding-up of an export pool can certainly cause problems. Our proposal would make it possible to wind it up at that time. Probable improvements in market conditions over the next two years will mean that the winding-up of an export pool will be able to be carried out with minimal disruption. I hope that the Government, which has taken this view with other industries, for example, the car industry, will take a similar view in relation to this industry and allow some time for adjustment.

The industry has agreed to meet this arrangement but it wants some time in which to bring itself into line. I think that is a fair and reasonable request. It seems that the Government's opposition is based on the fact that in two years time there will be an election year but I put it to the Government that this does not have anything to do with the industry, it has much more to do with the politics of this place. While that may seem terribly important to us, we are here dealing with the livelihoods of other people and we should try to take that into account as the demand should be on us to put their livelihoods ahead of ours.

The Dairy Produce Market Support Levy Bill provides for the imposition of a levy on the milk fat content of the relevant dairy products-whole milk and whole milk products. The maximum levy rate is 45c per kilogram of milk fat with the operative rate being established by regulation following a recommendation of the ADC. The levy is, of course, payable by the producer. I think it is important to keep emphasising that the people who are paying the bills are the people who are producing the products. The industry believes that the legislation should permit the Government, via regulation if possible, to introduce a two-price system by implementing a dual rate of levy. Regrettably, the Opposition parties have not been persuaded by the industry's arguments on this issue. It is particularly regrettable because in many respects the package of four proposals put by the industry are interdependent because of the divergent needs of the various States. Hence, I foreshadow that I will move in the Committee stage an amendment which will provide for that dual rate of levy. It will not impose it, it will merely leave open the possibilities of its being implemented by the Government if it wishes to do so. If it does not wish to do so there is no obligation on it actually to implement it. The amendment provides another mechanism which, I suggest, might be useful in the foreseeable future with regard to at least two States.

The final Bill is the Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy Amendment Bill, which is an integral part of the package and which imposes a levy on certain dairy products. Funds from the levy are intended to provide, as has happened in the past, support for domestic prices of dairy products. The Minister has said that the levies form part of the transitional arrangements designed to ease the movement over time to a lower level of support. I think that, as part of the package, it is something for which the industry must be commended for coming to grips with and for finally accepting. I admit it is not without a great deal of heartache that it has done that. One of the things that have to be said about the Minister for Primary Industry is that he has made some hard decisions, but it is a pity some of the harder decisions were not made in the past. If they had been we may not be in the position we are in today. Nevertheless, the arrangement the Government has chosen cannot be seen as the best arrangement. I admit there are differing arguments on this. Senator Cooney presented a proposition last night with regard to this. I believe that on balance it does fall on the other side. The industry is suggesting that it hold the support for two years and then have a phasing out period over the next four years-that is the same six-year time frame the Government has suggested-and that each of the last four years have a step down so that at the end of the period the situations which the industry and the Government are proposing will be the same. The essential difference is that the Government has chosen to do this via a complex formula. The difficulty there is predictability. I buy the theoretical point that Senator Cooney raised last night that under the Government's formula there is a theoretical possibility of higher returns to the growers. I do not think it is likely to occur, but it is a possibility and I accept Senator Cooney's proposition. Nevertheless, I believe and the industry believes-I think this is extremely important-that that predictability of staging down enables the growers to know what their returns will be ahead of time. Under the Government's proposals, that is not possible. The time frame about which we are talking can be up to 18 months. We are talking about products, and hence not just about the market milk operation.

It must be acknowledged that the industry, if it is willing to accept the theoretical possibility of lower prices, in opting for a predictable return ought to be listened to a little more seriously than it has been. I understand that this proposal is not necessarily one that the Department originally suggested and that it came from an outside group. If the Government returned to what I understand to be its original position, it would be worth while if this amendment-even if the others cannot be reconsidered-could be examined closely when it returns to the House of Representatives for reconsideration-hopefully, today.

In conclusion, I want to comment on one matter which is associated with but is not part of the legislative package before us today-the question of the adjustment mechanism which has been mentioned in the Press in recent weeks. The Minister has indicated publicly his willingness to work closely with State governments and industry to ensure that adjustment occurs in a fair and efficient manner, and it is pleasing to note that discussions have already been held with the Victorian Government. Despite some differences as to how to achieve the objective, the Government, the industry, the Australian Democrats, and, I am sure, the Opposition, would agree that humane rationalisation of an industry which is so beset with problems as the dairy industry is long overdue.

Let us hope that the Government will reconsider the amendments which, hopefully, the Senate will propose to the legislation, and consider them not as a belligerent attempt to attack the Government's plan but as an attempt to modify the plan in its implementation, so that the Government and industry can work together and put the industry on a firm basis. The industry provides an enormous amount to Australia. In particular, it provides so much to the families and to so many regions of this country. Let us hope that we do not have to go through the sort of head-kicking exercise that occurred in this chamber last night. Let us try to make sure that what we are doing is done in a way that will accommodate the variety of propositions that have been put. I still believe that there is the possibility of coming to an accommodation with regard to these various matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: — Today we are debating, cognately, a series of milk Bills-the Dairy Produce Market Support Levy Bill, the Dairy Legislation Amendment Bill, the Dairy Produce Market Support Bill and the Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy Amendment Bill-that will reduce another primary industry to rags. This series of Bills should be called the Kerin massacre because they prove once and for all that the Australian Labor Party does not care about the farmer-and not only that; it does not care for the person who works in a milk processing plant, who drives a truck, or who works in the dairy industry in any capacity.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills show no thought to any social consequence that may happen if they are implemented. They will bankrupt 2,000 to 3,000 farmers. They will destroy many good men and women who will stand at the front gates of their farms before the bailiff moves in. Those people will see their life's dreams, their work and their hopes all taken away from them. Anyone who tells me that the Labor Party is concerned for the battler after this series of Bills just does not understand. These Bills betray any social principles that the Labor Party ever had.

The Bills are aimed at reducing the milk quotas from six billion litres to 5.1 billion litres. The dairy industry realised that production had to be controlled. It had a plan that had the backing of every State dairy council in Australia and the backing of every State government Minister. It was put before Mr Kerin at an Agricultural Council meeting three days before the Victorian election. Two days after the election it was rejected by Mr Kerin-once again proving that he does not really care about the farmers. He tells them one thing out in the field, but he returns to Canberra and does exactly the opposite. We have seen it time and again. We see it now in the dairy industry, and we have seen it in the beef industry and the sugar industry.

I will not go into the Australian Dairy Industry Conference plan that was scrapped other than to say that it would not have cost the Government 1c to implement. The dairy industry would have imposed its own levies. It would have accepted a 10 per cent reduction in output and it would have put a heavy penalty on the overproduction of milk. That was the only way to bring the milk production into line at the minimum cost in human hurt.

What does Mr Kerin want? He wants a scheme that will come into place on 1 July and will ruin 3,000 dairy farmers-the final solution to the dairy problem. He says that the Australian people are paying much more for dairy products than they would if they were imported. This plan will wipe out the dairy industry and we will import yoghurt, butter, cheese and other dairy products. We will keep a few cows around to provide some fresh milk-enough for a cup of tea.

The dairy farmers are being asked to compete in a corrupt, prostituted world market that is subsidised by the taxpayers of the European Economic Community. The EEC farmers are paid huge amounts to produce milk and dairy products. The excess is being dumped for whatever price the EEC can get and the EEC taxpayer picks up the difference. Mr Kerin proposes a consumer transfer back to the people in the city to let them have milk at possibly 1c or 2c cheaper, with maybe a couple of cents saving per kilo on butter and cheese. That is the Kerin plan-export jobs and import food. This is the most disgusting piece of legislation I have seen. It is an academic plan that will cost Australia $100m in dole payments a year. It will destroy the lives of 3,000 dairy farmers and their families and will put 15,000 people in the dole queue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote that for you?

—I wrote it myself. Mr Kerin is doing this in the name of deregulation. I have said time and time again that I am for deregulation. Everyone in my Party believes in deregulation. My Party supports the principle, but deregulation cannot be selective. We cannot expect the great primary industries of this nation to carry millions of dollars in tariff protection-$9,000 a year for each farmer, and we have 170,000 farmers, which works out at $1.53 billion. That is consumer transfer in tariff protection from the country to the city. The Australian Labor Party believes that farmers are feather-bedded and receive huge government subsidies.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the subsidies that secondary industries have received since this Government came into power. The level of government assistance to secondary industry over the last 10 years has fallen from 36 per cent to 28 per cent. It has fallen from 28 per cent to 8 per cent in the case of primary industry. But the Government continues to put forward its line of argument on deregulation in primary industry. I have taken the trouble to ask the Parliamentary Library to prepare a list of legislation that has come through this House since the Government came to power giving protection to secondary industry in the form of government assistance. The Government has given $176m to the steel industry to get it back on its feet. It has given $150m to the car industry, which is dominated by multinationals and has a low level of Australian ownership, unlike the dairy industry, which consists of family farms and is the basis of family society. It has given $70m to the Australian National Line. It has imposed new tariffs to protect many secondary industries, such as tariffs on air conditioners, injection moulding equipment, electric motors, computers, and, of course, agricultural equipment. Those are just a few examples. The Government has also increased research funding for secondary industry. I do not want to run those proposals down. My Party voted for them, but I point to the inconsistencies in this Government's policies. There is one rule for primary industry and another for secondary industry. Secondary industry receives a whole host of government assistance. Primary industry gets nothing, despite having to operate in a corrupt world market, having to support secondary industry through the transfer of tariff and being slugged with ever increasing charges by this Government.

In contrast, let us examine what primary industry has lost since this Government came to power. The Government has increased inspection charges on meat by 200 per cent and it has increased charges on a wide variety of other primary products, including eggs, edible oil, honey, wheat and dried fruit. It has abolished the income equalisation deposits scheme, imposed a 15 per cent tariff on grain harvesters and abolished the drought fodder and interest payment subsidies for drought sufferers. It has also imposed a 10 per cent sales tax on wine, cut funds for the rural adjustment scheme by 40 per cent, from $44m to $28m, cancelled the bicentenary water resources program and cut the petroleum products freight subsidy by $130m. We have seen constant increases in aviation fuel excise and a callous and total disregard for the election promise to the sugar industry to implement a sugar underwriting scheme. It has diverted funds accrued from the 2c a litre levy on fuel from the Fraser Government's road projects to general revenue. There have been real cuts in funding for rural research and the emphasis in the Department of Trade has moved from primary industry to secondary industry. The introduction of the assets test has hit primary industry the hardest due to the rule which does not allow rural pensioners exemption for their landholdings. The list goes on and on.

This Parliament has provided millions of dollars to support the jobs of people working in factories in and around Melbourne and Sydney. I am sure these people would not mind paying an extra 20c or 30c to have an Australian dairy product on their breakfast table. There are double standards in this Government; it has one set of rules for the country and another for the city. Mr Kerin's plan is an academic plan because he is a product of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. He is the nearest thing to a farmer that the Australian Labor Party has to put up as Minister for Primary Industry but he is receiving his instructions from the BAE. If Mr Kerin wants to put world parity prices on dairy products I suggest that he also put them on the BAE. We have an academic Minister backed by academics; so the people in the bush have become cannon fodder for this Government. They are numbers, statistics. What is the ruination of 3,000 people to a Primary Industry Minister who has a super-safe seat in the western suburbs of Sydney?

Not only will this legislation affect the dairy farmers and people who work in the dairy factories but also it will affect thousands of small businesses-the milk vendors of Australia. The Government has the mistaken belief that if prices are reduced by taking away deregulation the market will rise. That is a complete fallacy. In fact, even when the milk vendors are forced out of business people will not buy their milk from the supermarkets in any great quantity; so the consumption of milk will fall. We will see heavy discounting by the bigger supermarkets and that also will affect the smaller family businesses. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Kerin plan for the rationalisation of the dairy industry as it now stands would be absolutely disastrous, not only for the industry but also for the whole Australian economy. At present, even with depressed world prices, dairy production is worth over $2 billion annually to Australia; that is, when one adds the value of meat from the dairy farmers and the added value of dairy processing. But dairy farmers are realists and they are the first to acknowledge that the industry is in dire trouble. The essential cause of the problem faced by the industry is the collapse of world market prices brought about by very severe oversupply of dairy products world-wide. Unfortunately, this collapse in world market prices has coincided with the expansion in the Australian production of milk. Few countries produce milk as efficiently as Australia. Farmers in Europe receive approximately $A6 per kilogram of butter fat and farmers in North America receive approximately $A11 per kilogram of butter fat, but Australian farmers receive only $2.50 to $3 per kilogram of butter fat for milk which is used for manufacture, which is about 75 per cent. That discrepancy in prices is just hopeless.

SPEECH.PARA: It is against that scenario that we have seen the introduction of this cruel so-called Kerin plan. While few countries can match the efficiency of Australian dairy farmers in milk production, the European Economic Community and the United States of America have created mountains of surplus butter, cheese, et cetera, which has been sold on world markets with a heavy subsidy. This is but one of my most stringent criticisms of the so-called Kerin plan, because it penalises dairy farmers for market forces beyond their control.

The main thrust of the proposed new marketing arrangements is supposed to be a deregulated, 'let market forces apply' approach. While the scheme is supposed to be deregulatory, the Australian Dairy Corporation will be required to appoint more staff to administer the scheme. So much for deregulation. However, this is an absurd objective, given the present world market for dairy produce. It could not have come about at a worse time. The Australian dairy industry does not operate in a free world market. The heavy protection effected by the EEC, the United States and New Zealand towards their domestic producers has in fact corrupted the world market. This is the essential point I made to Senator Cooney last night-the corrupted world market, because no other dairy industry in the world relies solely on revenue from the so-called world market or uses these corrupted prices that apply on the world market to determine domestic prices. But this is the thrust of the Kerin plan-using corrupted prices and trying to sell it off as a free market type proposal.

It is interesting to contrast the Federal Government's attitude towards the dairy industry with its contribution of more than $2 billion which eventually comes into the economy from this great industry which directly employs 50,000 to 60,000 people, with the recent discussions on the Bounty (Injection-moulding Equipment) Amendment Bill in which the Government's decision to continue assistance to the one remaining manufacturer in Australia amounts to about a $40,000 subsidy per worker for the next four years. That gives some idea of the imbalance and the injustice in this plan which has been put forward.

Many of the dairy industry's problems are not of its own making. The Federal Government needs to be reminded of this when framing the rationalisation of the dairy industry. One of the most striking observations that has emerged from the furore surrounding the proposals of the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr John Kerin, is the degree of rationalisation that has already occurred within the industry. Over the last 20 years the number of dairy farms in production has fallen from 49,000 in 1964 to 18,000 in 1985. There has been a further rationalisation since 1977 as demonstrated by the fact that there has been a 28 per cent increase in the number of dairy farms with more than 200 cows and a concurrent fall of 70 per cent in the number of farms with less than 100 cows. Since 30 April 1980 the number of registered dairy farmers in my State of Tasmania has dropped by the alarming number of 280, in that small State. At 30 March this year there were 1,242 dairy farmers in Tasmania.

There is a general agreement among dairymen, manufacturers, State governments and the Federal Government that the dairy industry is in trouble and needs a degree of restructuring. Despite an already traumatic period of rationalisation since the 1960s, it is clear that there will be a further contraction of the industry with or without the Kerin plan. The Cain plan, finalised on the eve of the Victorian elections, could have rationalised the industry by the introduction of a two-price scheme. A number of commentators have expressed the opinion that the first reaction of dairy farmers under the Kerin plan, rather than to reduce production, will be to produce more milk in order to try to maintain their incomes and to meet their high debt repayments. That is quite contrary to the intention of the proposals. In fact, the hoped for reduction of milk flow will not eventuate until 1986-87 or 1987-88 when large numbers will leave the industry simply because they and their families can no longer work the long hours-over 80 hours per week-for little reward. This is in contrast to what is happening in some of the public sector areas, where there are demands for reduced working hours. The dairy farmers will be asked to work longer hours for less pay. That is not very democratic.

Another aspect of the Kerin scheme which disturbs me and those closely associated with the industry is the nature and make-up of the group upon which this impetus for contraction will fall. Rather than forcing out the inefficient farmers, it will force out the young farming families, particularly those in Victoria and Tasmania-those poor people who have taken the best advice from the Federal and State governments and who have taken on high debt loads in order to modernise their production. These are the ones who will be forced to cease their operations as dairymen. Those dairy farmers are also acknowledged as the most efficient in the country-a tragedy. By forcing efficient producers out of the market over the next few years and entrenching inefficient farmers, the Kerin plan will ensure that the problems of rationalisation of the dairy industry continue to plague the industry over the next decade.

It is proposed that the Kerin plan will be inaugurated at the beginning of July. As it stands at present, its impact will be disastrous. It is an ambitious plan which aims to do too much too quickly. What is needed is an orderly transition into the new marketing arrangements and a slower phasing-out of the existing arrangements which would prevent unnecessary exits from the industry.

The Tasmanian Minister for Primary Industry recently advised Mr Kerin of a number of modifications that the Tasmanian Government felt would make the transition much less traumatic and less chaotic nationally. Those amendments have also been supported by the dairy industry. They do not attempt to alter the thrust of the Kerin plan but rather to achieve a smoother transition from the current arrangements to the new plan. What is wrong with that?

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the cost?
—A smoother and less traumatic transition is what is needed.
—What was the cost?

—Under the current arrangements export pools are conducted by the Australian Dairy Corporation on five products-butter, cheddar cheese, skim milk powder, casein and whole milk powder. The pooling arrangements have operated in one form or another for almost 50 years. Export pooling involves no taxpayer contribution or additional consumer subsidy to the industry. The Government has decided that the export pooling system will be abolished as from 1 July 1985. Removal of export pooling without giving the industry any opportunity to make necessary adjustments to accommodate the changes will have catastrophic effects. It will cause significant price cutting on the local market and in preferred export markets. Manufacturers who are unable to place products on the better returning export markets will have no option but to undercut other suppliers to the domestic market, or the more profitable export markets where they exist. The effect will be an erosion of domestic prices and a loss of export revenue to the industry and to Australia as a whole. For the benefit of the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, that will be the cost. That will be the cost to everybody.

SPEECH.PARA: The export pooling system is also a fundamental component of the industry's financing arrangements. Export pooling, in combination with underwriting, provides a guaranteed floor price from which the Australian Dairy Corporation can make advances to the industry in the form of product loans. Removal of export pooling will mean that there will be no guaranteed minimum value for product. As a consequence, the Australian Dairy Corporation's advance to the industry will have to be set at relatively conservative rates. The effect on the farmer will be an initial opening price of 80c to $1 per kilogram of butter fat lower than would be the case under the existing arrangements.

The most savage part of the Kerin plan is that farmers will be given no more than a few weeks notice that the whole financing arrangement that has underpinned the industry in the past is to be thrown out. Through delayed payments for milk, the burden of financing the industry's operations will, under the Kerin plan, be carried by the farmers. The amendments which the Government introduced to its original proposals in the House of Representatives will at best have a marginal effect on this problem. The industry and the Opposition are not proposing that the Government should continue export pooling indefinitely; simply that it should delay for two years abolition of the pools on two of the five products-butter and cheese. The Government argues that there are no advantages to delaying the phasing-out of the pools. This is nonsense.

There are at least four reasons why the industry would be in a much better position two years down the track to accommodate phasing-out of the pooling system. The first is that it is likely that by 1987-88 milk production will have begun to decline. As a result, the industry will not have the chronic surplus of products to dispose of on low price export markets as it does at present.

The second reason is that the international market prices for dairy products are cyclical. It is likely that by 1987-88 international prices will have improved from their current disastrously low levels. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics supports this view.

The third point is that, under the Kerin plan, export support will be provided to currently non-leviable products and distortions in the system which disadvantage certain products will then be corrected. Corrections of these anomalies in the current system should see the expansion, possibly even the doubling, of exports of non-traditional dairy products by 1987-88. To the extent to which this occurs, exports of bulk products, for example, butter and cheese will be reduced, thus reducing the necessity for an export pool on these products. The fourth reason is that two years notice of termination of export pools will give both farmers and manufacturers lead time to adjust their financial arrangements to accommodate relatively lower product loans from the Australian Dairy Corporation and, consequently, lower opening prices for milk.

Let me comment on the phase-out of domestic product levies. Under the Government's proposals domestic product levies would be maintained at a level which would support the existing domestic market prices during 1985-86 but would be phased out in accordance with the formula from 1986-87 right through to 1990-91. There are two issues of concern regarding the Government's proposals in respect of the phasing out of product levies. Firstly, while the Government claims its proposal maintains support levels for 12 months in practical terms it maintains support for only six months production at farm level. Under the new legislation product levies are applied at a rate appropriate at the time of sale. While 63,000 tonnes of cheddar cheese produced in 1985-86 will be sold on the domestic market, only 25,000 to 30,000 tonnes will be sold during this financial year. The remainder will be sold in 1986-87, when support levels will be substantially reduced. Manufacturers of cheese must determine the price which they will pay farmers in 1985-86 on the basis of domestic support levels in 1985-86 and 1986-87, the latter being as yet unknown. The Opposition amendment continues current support levels until July 1987, which in practical terms means 18 months production. That is a reasonable approach. Secondly, the formula results in an unreasonably high rate of adjustment in the first year in which it would apply. Most industry observers believe that milk production in 1985-86 is likely to be about 6,000m litres or about the same level as in 1984-85. Similarly, most observers do not anticipate a substantial reduction, if any, in market milk prices.

Given this scenario, the Government's formula would result in a 50 per cent reduction in product levies between 30 June 1986 and 1 July 1987. It was 60 per cent prior to the Government's amendment being introduced into the House of Representatives. If half of the levy has gone in the first year the effect of the formula adjusting the rate of phase-out of the other 50 per cent of the levy is of little practical significance. The industry's suggestion, which the Opposition supports, is simply to phase out the product levies in four equal steps from 1987-88 until 1990-91. In this way there is no uncertainty regarding future support levels. The industry needs certainty. The industry and the Government know precisely the rate at which the industry's support will, therefore, be phased out. This amendment may or may not result in higher support in a particular area or year. It does, however, make support levels much more predictable.

Let me now comment on the method of determining market support payments. The Government has proposed that market support payments be related to a fixed percentage, say, 130 per cent of a three-year moving average of export prices. The intention is to measure these prices on an f.o.b. basis. The concern expressed by the industry and shared by the Opposition is that this system could result in anomalies. An amendment to overcome these anomalies has been suggested. But the Government has rejected this amendment in the House of Representatives on the basis that the target price mechanism reflects market prices. In fact, it does not do so. The target price is related to market returns during the two previous seasons, and the estimate of price in the forthcoming season is made up two months prior to the season commencing. There is no certainty that the target price so determined will reflect market prices during the year in question. Because of this, certain anomalies can arise. Whole milk powder is a good example. The existing marketing arrangement disadvantages whole milk powder as an export product. As a result only the very best whole milk powder markets were supplied. Consequently, the target price for whole milk powder, which reflects historical prices for whole milk powder under the old marketing system, is excessively high when compared with butter and skim milk powder.

The effect of the Opposition amendment to clause 19 of the Dairy Produce Market Support Bill is to give the industry some control over the products to which this target price mechanism for determining export market support payments is to be applied. It should be stressed that the products excluded from this system are not disadvantaged. Under section 20 of the Bill the Australian Dairy Corporation is obliged to set market support payments for these products at a level which is 'appropriate to the other products'. The suggestion by the Minister that the amendments will discriminate against certain companies, I believe, is a nonsense.

There is one further issue which I believe the Government should address; that is, the question of subsidised or dumped cheese. There are almost no restrictions on imports of dairy products into Australia. As a result Australia has become the dumping ground for other countries surpluses, particularly in cheese. The Australian industry has successfully taken countervailing action against imports of certain European Economic Community and Norwegian cheeses, but the process of securing countervailing protection is slow and very cumbersome, as we have found in other areas. For example, the industry first applied the countervailing duties on EEC edam, gouda and blue vein cheeses in August 1982. A prima facie case was established in June 1983. The case was not finalised until December 1983, six months later, when the EEC agreed, under duress, to reduce but not remove its export subsidies on certain varieties of cheese and then not all varieties exported to Australia. The Corporation did not advise the Government-or the appropriate question was not asked-that the EEC exporters would be able to ship cheese from Europe at the pre-arranged subsidy rate up until July 1984. Shipments arrived in Australia at the old subsidy rates up until September or October 1984. The effect of the countervailing duty, initiated in August 1982, was not felt in the market-place until December 1984. That is some two and a half years later. What further proof is necessary that the existing measures to protect the industry against subsidised imports are not working satisfactorily?

There is a further problem for the Australian cheese industry related to the enforcement of Australian food laws. Australian producers are not permitted to add sodium nitrate and certain other preservatives to cheese but European cheeses sold on the Australian market frequently contain these additives. Either all cheese sold in this country should be required to conform to Australian food standards or we should drop our own food regulations and adopt European standards. As it now stands, the food regulations are a significant disadvantage to the Australian industry in competing with European cheeses. I deeply deplore the statements made by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, and his attitude towards the Opposition's amendments. I hope he will reconsider his position in the interests of the Australian nation, but particularly in the interests of the Australian dairy farmers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Dairy Produce Market Support Levy Bill 1985, the Dairy Legislation Amendment Bill 1985, the Dairy Produce Market Support Bill 1985 and the Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy Amendment Bill 1985 introduced cognately into this House yesterday by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh. SPEECH.PARA: A decade ago, there were some 388 factories in the dairy industry employing 21,700 people. Today there are some 264 factories with a work force of some 17,900 people. Since 1979-80, milk production has fallen from 7.2 billion litres to the six billion litres it is today. The industry is rationalising. I believe that it is a responsible industry, contrary to the beliefs of Senator Black, judging from the way he spoke a little while ago. The industry produces high quality milk which costs some 40c a bottle, which is a very low price to pay for such a good food. In 1970-71, the total number of farms was over 37,000. Today, the number of dairy farms is some 19,000. The dairy industry contributes between 3 to 4 per cent of total exports of rural origin. Farm incomes in the dairy industry are crucially affected by the prices of market and manufacturing milk. Surplus production must either be sold on unprofitable export markets or placed in storage. A point has already been made about the European Economic Community, which is the source of some 60 per cent of total world exports. Those exports come from a highly subsidised area. Nineteen per cent of the total exports of world supplies comes from New Zealand, which is also subsidised, nine per cent comes from the United States of America and five per cent comes from Australia.

The immediate outlook for the dairy industry is depressed due to the problems of low prices, rising costs and declining incomes. Current marketing arrangements have encouraged milk output beyond that required in profitable marketing outlets. The industry is rationalising. It needs time. The Kerin plan, the academics' plan or the bureaucrats' plan-whatever one likes to call it-whilst containing a number of provisions relevant to the industry, also includes some totally unnecessary and unacceptable, harsh provisions which will badly destabilise the moderate, progressive steps of the industry towards rationalisation. The Kerin plan, as introduced to this House by the Government, is a recipe for social and economic chaos within the dairy industry which will affect the livelihood and security of thousands of families. Hardship, heartbreak, relocation and the breakdown of communities will occur.

The industry, the Opposition parties and the Government are pursuing similar goals. However, the legislation fails to recognise that some time must be given to the industry if any adjustment proposal is to work to enable farmers, factory managers and those employed in the industry to prepare themselves for a new and tough environment. Industry unrest could be overcome if the Government were to take another look at the speed with which it is trying to achieve lower production levels. Perhaps if the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) had consulted as much with the dairy industry as the Labor Government consults with the Australian Council of Trade Unions on other matters many of the amendments in the legislation would not have been necessary and the dairy industry would have got what it wanted, as would the Australian community. For the benefit of those on the other side who do not know much about farming I say that it takes time to reduce herd numbers and levels of production. There is an average six-month lag between the production and sale of dairy products, that is, milk used for purposes other than domestic fresh milk consumption. Breeding programs take a while. They take something like 2 1/2 years to bring to consummation, which is different from what honourable senators opposite would think.

No other industry in Australia has ever had such a brutal ultimatum handed to it. The Opposition has three main areas of concern. The first area of concern is export pooling. The second area of concern is with the provision in the legislation that current domestic prices be maintained for two years instead of one year, to give more time to the industry. The third concern is that it is essential to ensure that the way in which support payments are established is even-handed between co-operative and proprietary companies. Mr Kerin, in introducing this legislation, has squandered the opportunity to negotiate an effective milk supply management plan which will prevent either chronic surpluses or shortages of supply to the Australian domestic export markets. The dairy industry is not heavily supported by taxpayers' funds. The Kerin plan threatens irreparable harm to our dairy export trade. The Minister's Department, and the Minister himself, do not even know how far production will drop under this legislation, although the dairy industry predicts that we will end up barely being able to supply our domestic needs. There is a real fear that we may lose our self-sufficiency and that the Kerin plan could result ultimately in a sell-out to the New Zealand dairy industry. The $20m offered for reconstruction will not compensate for the exodus of some 20,000 to 25,000 people who will be forced out of this great industry. The loss of jobs could cost taxpayers some $2m per week in welfare payments.

Problems of this plan do not affect just the farmers, manufacturers and employees. The Australian Oilseeds Federation has joined the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation in calling for a more equitable, predictable and rational dairy plan. The AOF can see that a short term, downward movement in dairy prices towards world dumped prices threatens its industry. As soon as the world market shifts away from a dumped price, Australia could find itself with inadequate supplies, not only of dairy products but also of oilseed products. The oilseed industry says:
The result-
of this plan--

would be serious disruption of the margarine industry with substantial job losses . . . We believe the Government is planning to proceed 'too fast too soon' without sufficient consideration of our industry.

I cite some figures in a paper I have which gives the views of the Australian Oilseeds Federation as to the effects of the Kerin dairy marketing plan. There are some 15,000 oilseed growers at the moment in Australia producing some 700,000 tonnes of oilseeds. By 1985-86, Australia will be self-sufficient in soft oils, providing valuable, alternative crops to wheat. Hence the point I am making about the flow-on effects of the dairy plan to other primary industries in Australia. The crushing industry has a capital investment of some $75m and employs some 500 persons. The margarine industry has a capital investment of $200m and employs some 2,000 people. In 1983-84 the consumption in Australia of margarine was some 148,000 tonnes, or 71 per cent of total margarine and butter production in Australia. Currently-this is the point I would like to make-butter and polyunsaturated margarine have similar shelf prices. Intense competition between the products is good. Strong brand competition between margarine companies ensures consumer protection.

The effect of the Kerin plan could be to reduce the price of butter from $2,400-odd a tonne to $1,600-odd a tonne by 1991-1992. Higher costs of vegetable oils coupled with reduced butter prices will cause an estimated loss of sales of margarine of 25,000 tonnes. Honourable senators might ask why I am talking about the margarine industry when we are debating a dairy Bill. The reason is that the flow-on effects both in and out of that industry to the wheat industry and the farming community will be felt as they will have to relocate their efforts and resources a lot more than Mr Kerin bargained for when he introduced these Bills.

Another industry that will be affected will be the milk vending industry. At the moment there are some 4,500 milk vendors in Australia and their livelihoods are at stake with this Bill. A letter from the Amalgamated Milk Vendors Association of Queensland states in part:
Milk vendors cater for the less fortunate-the infirm, elderly and disadvantaged members of the public.
They are obviously people who have not been considered in the introduction of this Bill brought down by the Government. The letter continues:
Vendors take great pride in delivering under the most adverse conditions such as those created through floods, cyclones, industrial disputations--
we have plenty of them at the moment--

and other natural disasters. Fresh milk is supplied daily and consumers are offered a choice of pack. Vendors also give a service to customers requiring small amounts of milk (e.g. one bottle twice a week) and this service can only be maintained whilst there are viable balanced runs catering for both small and large deliveries. If the eyes are picked out by Supermarkets, this valued service--
will be lost to the community. The letter continues:

In regional and remote country areas which are already under severe industry stress, the service provided by Milk Vendors and the value of associated industry business is of even . . . greater significance.

Nowhere is cognizance paid to the importance and value of the role of the Milk Vendor in marketing white milk and dairy products, nor is there any specific reference to an intended role envisaged under Mr Kerin's National Dairy Plan.
Much emphasis is made by the B.A.E.--
that point has already been made here today as obviously Mr Kerin is taking a lot of notice of it-
and others to a resultant reduction in the retail price of milk to the consumer and the alleged assumption that such action will lead to an appreciable increase in sales.
Such hypothesis is not accepted--

Another industry that will be affected is the beef industry, especially the home trade beef industry, because if the dairy farmers are forced out of being milk suppliers they will go into vealer production and most probably cause an oversupply in our home beef market.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what they want, cheap meat!

—Thank you, Senator Boswell. The Government wants the whole of the rural industry to be put into the hands of the receivers. That is the socialist dream, to get the rural industry right under its thumb. It is unrealistic for Mr Kerin to attempt suddenly to apply a so-called deregulated market force approach to the dairy industry which is competing on a world market severely distorted by EEC dumping. In short, the Government is prepared to forgo virtually $350m to $400m in dairy product export revenue built up over many decades. This will only give the EEC planners an incentive to do the same to our efficient sugar, wheat, beef, sheep meats and other industries. Australia cannot afford to abandon multimillion dollar export industries at a time of high overseas borrowings and extensive repayment problems. Those problems have been brought to the notice of this House many times. Mr Kerin's plan, and the way in which it was introduced into this House yesterday by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, with the threat that the Government will not accept the amendments that have been suggested by the Opposition, smacks of stand-over tactics, blackmail and the holding of a gun at the heads of all senators, all dairy farmers and the people of Australia. As I have said, the industry recognises the problem of overproduction of milk and it is rationalising itself. It needs time to restructure. It is using self-help techniques to do this. Give it time. SPEECH.PARA: I respect the fact that the Government brings down legislation. I respect the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, and the job he is endeavouring to do as far as the milk industry is concerned. I do not believe that the Government intends to wreck the milk industry. I do believe that a considerable amount of misjudgment, misinformation and misunderstanding has gone into the formulation of the legislation. I see it as my position to raise those matters to include a human element in the legislation and to demonstrate what the future holds. I ask the Government to consider those points while we all work for what is best.

I do not enter the debate to do anything more than secure this opportunity to bring about a stable, profitable and long term dairy industry. I start off by making some comments on considerations that I believe are often overlooked concerning the production, consumption and the export of dairy products. Firstly, Australian dairy produce can be and is produced at a cost less than that of every other country in the world-most of all, New Zealand. That is efficiency. Not too many industries can say that. Secondly, it is in every State and the governments of those States have had to take action to establish a stable and high quality milk supply all year round at a price that can ensure such supply is maintained. In spite of the implications to the contrary, the only reason we have a price set up for fresh milk from State to State is that it reflects the need and desire of the States to have milk and to pay the price that is necessary to procure it; nothing more, nothing less. Lower prices would, in their opinion, prejudice their ability to maintain quality and/or continuity. What is not readily understood is that the supply fluctuates considerably due to season and climatic circumstance. Milk flow varies for a whole variety of reasons and in order to secure a minimum quantity of milk in the difficult months of the year a surplus automatically flows in the peak periods. Out of season milk is expensive to produce and no dairy farmer milks on a year round basis unless he gets adequate compensation for doing so.

To cut 25 per cent from the present total Australian production would, without doubt, require an increase in domestic milk prices to ensure production in the worst months of the off season. The balance, of course, goes to the production of those other products-cheese, butter, powder and so on-and the worst problem that the processing sector has is coping with a fluctuating milk flow and the utilisation of capital investment, plant and staff.

I find it quite extraordinary that even in this great rural country there are still people by the millions who believe that milk is what one gets out of a bottle. As far as export is concerned, every item we sell is valuable to our economy. Four hundred million dollars of export income is $400m. This country only achieved its greatness on account of the primary products that it sold overseas. It was not the secondary and tertiary sectors that made Australia great, even though they have their place today.

There is much talk of consumers paying a distorted price for dairy products. I ask the Minister: Where in this world is there absolutely no distortion in the price of dairy products? Where can he find a true price? I received an information document from the Library recently. In part, on page 7, it states:
The best proxy for world prices are those received by producers in New Zealand since that country exports most of its output under close to free-market conditions, as outlined below.

I contest that very solidly. I suggest that the 11.7c per kilogram or per litre, as the case may be, is just as much an artificial figure as is the 27.8c for the United States, 25.2c for West Germany, and 21.6c for Great Britain. In my opinion, the New Zealand cost is clearly more than that. It is based on only the accounted section of the inputs. One has to consider that the New Zealanders have a whole range of non-accounted inputs, including, for instance, a $750m loan to the dairy authority at one per cent interest. Of course, this represents a subsidy of 20c a kilogram on every kilogram of product handled in that country.
In the New Zealand Commodity Report of 10 May, the price of manufacturing milk in New Zealand was given as follows:
Final payments for the 1984-85 season are expected to amount to 8 to 9c per kilogram over and above the basic price of 381c per kilogram.

In other words, the New Zealand price for manufacturing milk will be 390c a kilogram. That price converts to about 260c Australian, which is almost exactly the same as Australian producers are paid in my State of Tasmania. As I have said, the 11.7c is just the accounted portion of the New Zealand milk price. Australia, too, produces a very low cost milk and has very little undisclosed cost; so I do not want anybody to tell me that Australian milk is dear.

They do not pay too much, and they pay much less than consumers in every comparable country, except New Zealand. For 50 years, under dairy equalisation and pooling, we have concentrated on securing the best world prices available. Initially, the equalisation scheme arranged for bulk butter to be sold to the United Kingdom. After the United Kingdom's entry to the European Economic Community, the dairy corporation pool was established, and it has produced, without argument, the best prices available for our export products, and at least as high a price as that secured by any other exporting country. Contrary to everything that the Government has said, the system of pooling rewards good marketing and penalises bad marketing.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cooney did a good job last night in speaking to the notes that he was given. He made five points against pooling. I regret that all five points he raised were wrong. Pooling does not tend to make the cost to consumers higher. That is rubbish. It does not encourage overproduction. How could it? It does not provide greater assistance to the lowest value product. The farmers who moved into the industry, particularly after the 1976 shake-down, are a great group. They are basically in the 30 to 45 age group. They are highly skilled. SPEECH.PARA: I was horrified when the Government said that it had not carried out any investigation of the impacts of the proposition. There is no information on which locations are likely to be most affected, how many farmers are likely to be affected and to what extent rural towns and communities will be affected. Clearly, there will be a range of actions taken by farmers over the next twelve months as they make decisions on their future.

Perhaps the Minister who replies to this debate will tell us some of the real alternatives. How can we keep the older people on the farms when we now have an assets test that prevents them even from living on the farms they have owned for years, after these farms have ceased to provide them with a living?
