TALK.START.PARA: —This letter speaks for dozens of rural communities not only in Tasmania but Australia-wide. I was very touched by that letter. I ask that Government members contemplate it carefully. I was surprised at Senator Cooney's speech. He was the only Government member to speak on the legislation. At no stage in his speech did he mention people. I do not understand why this Government has chosen to make the producers of food the scapegoats for the nation's excessive cost structure. To follow this logic does no more than to export Australian jobs to countries that provide enormous subsidies so that we can import our food from them. I was pleased that the word 'consensus' came into discussions earlier. I notice that on one occasion the Minister for Primary Industry said:

SPEECH.PARA: After long and comprehensive consultations and negotiations with the States and with industry . . .

I remind the Senate that any impression that there was agreement is purely accidental. There was a series of meetings and everyone except Mr Kerin agreed. So one could be excused for thinking that there was agreement all round. A Press release of 1 March-this was a very important day-from the office of the Minister for Primary Industry stated:
The Minister for Primary Industry, John Kerin, said that Premier Cain's intervention has meant that agreement was able to be reached by the States on the central elements of the ADIC plan.
The Minister said:
I have always promised the industry that I would take ADIC to the Cabinet . . .
Later on he said:
The States now have agreement on a 2 cent/litre levy and that they will not trade market milk interstate.
In keeping with my consistent position on the ADIC plan I will convey the agreement reached to my Cabinet Colleagues . . .

I believe that those statements give an impression which is more true now than it was at the time they were made. It is distasteful that such a document was ever produced. How can the returns be improved? Is there more money in the system? I was listening to a representative of the Canadian dairy industry recently, who said that producers in his country get 80 per cent of the retail price of milk. In the Industries Assistance Commission report there is a schedule dated 1 October 1983 which shows that in Victoria 40 per cent of the price goes to the producer and 60 per cent goes to other interests that take a slice along the way. I do not know why Australian producers should have so much trouble getting paid a reasonable price for their products.

On several occasions the Minister for Primary Industry has made mention of the national industry concept. I must respond on the basis that setting one State against another and every processor against every other processor will not and could not achieve that aim. The results would be exactly the opposite. To remove the fundamentals of the arrangement with New Zealand on dairy marketing can only encourage our friends across the Tasman also to ignore the arrangement. If they do, Australia and her industry will suffer most. I implore the Government not to do anything that would damage or destroy a very sensible arrangement, one which I hope could be extended to other industries for a similar good purpose.

I ask the Government also to consider the price of milk in the EEC countries. It should add to that price the normal cost of production, holding and transport charges, and apply countervailing duties across the board where it is apparent that product is reaching us at low prices. I also draw attention, as did Senator Watson, to the fact that approximately 10,000 tonnes of cheese enters Australia every year which fails to pass the fundamental health standards applied to Australian production. I ask that the Government ensure that the health standards of imported cheese be no lower than those required for Australian produced cheese. That sector alone involves well over 100 million litres of milk per annum, and I believe we could start there.

Over the past two months farmers, processors and State governments have presented their cases and facts in Canberra in an excellent manner. I must say that the industry is in very good hands. Even though this debate cannot produce the result that has been agreed upon by the various State governments and the industry, that certainly is not for the want of effort and the manner in which the dairy industry has put its case. I congratulate it for that.

I draw attention to the facts relating to the manufacturers as well as to the producers. Since the 1977 legislation the industry has complied with everything that the law required. It has done all those things requested of it. It has amalgamated, modernised, automated and chased markets, and many parts of the industry have changed their product pattern to a very considerable degree.

In summing up in the other place the Minister made a gratuitous comment about the fact that the Opposition had just taken the advice of the industry. His comment was anything but complimentary. Clearly that was not so. The Opposition at no stage accepted the proposition that the industry put forward. The Opposition went through the case very thoroughly with the industry. The Opposition negotiated with the industry, reduced and refined its plan and did everything possible to come up with a case that we believed was absolutely impeccable. We had a lot of difficulty trying to get the industry to stick with the agreements that were made. We need to bear in mind the fact that the Minister's comment was so inaccurate. Perhaps if the Minister had listened to the industry more we would not be in the mess we are now in. Mr Wright, a member in the other place, suggested that we not worry about it. His advice was just to get started and wait and see. Rural areas of Australia have been watching the Canberra performance fairly closely and many country people will be looking at the support given to the industry by the incumbents of various seats. Those incumbents include the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall), the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler), the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb), the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham), the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren), the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) and the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright). I suggest that some of those members ought to be looking over their shoulders right now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the way we should determine an industry structure, Senator? Is that what you are saying? That is what you are saying, isn't it?

—I am saying that those members will have their performances judged in the electorate. That is something we should all consider. Many speakers in the overall debate on the dairy industry have made much of protection, support, market forces, efficiency and so on. They have used all those modern buzz words. I just wonder what they are talking about. How can one operate on what is a real market price? How can one work with a free market force when the greatest single cost is so totally protected? How can one compare efficiency when various factors are totally controlled-for example, the cost of wages? How can one judge performance while that is the case?

SPEECH.PARA: Again I commend the industry on the way it has taken every step possible over the last couple of years to try to get changes made. It knows what changes are necessary and has endeavoured to institute them. It was the industry which brought forward all the points we have been considering. Not a soul is arguing about the need to curtail production; no one is arguing that we need a cut and shut industry, but we do want to know what it is going to be like and we want some choice for the people presently in the industry. Our argument concerns the insensitivity of the plan, the total arrogant disregard of its social and financial impact. Whole rural communities will suffer.

I list nine problems resulting from the legislation. It will do nothing to control production next year; probably it will have the reverse effect. It totally destroys the current market signals and replaces them with historic prices; it upsets our relationship with New Zealand, based on our memorandum of agreement; and it destroys our concept of a national industry by playing every State against every manufacturer. Milk prices can never go up by the 30c that the Minister has been talking about; they can only come down. There can be no less regulation. Regulation will be shifted more to the States and will involve more Australian Dairy Corporation staff. Pooling is just not understood by the Minister and his Government, and the enormous financial involvement of both Government and industry in this plan could be alleviated if the implementation of the plan were delayed for just a bit longer. I ask that for the industry's good the Government reconsider these points that have been put forward.

I note in passing that with the exception of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) only two Australian Labor Party senators have participated in this very important debate. Indeed only Senator Cooney even attempted to address the central issues. There are certain issues I wish to touch on because of the importance of the dairy industry on a national basis and because 60 per cent of the industry is concentrated in my own State of Victoria. Almost 90 per cent of Victorian milk production goes into manufactured dairy products-a higher proportion than in any other State except Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: The importance of the dairy industry is often overlooked. It directly employs about 57,000 people; 40,000 of them on almost 20,000 dairy farms and 17,000 or more in some 260 dairy factories around Australia. Many more people's livelihoods depend indirectly on the industry, particularly in country areas. The total value of dairy production exceeds $1,000m per annum, or approximately 8 per cent of the gross value of Australia's total rural production. It contributes between $350m and $400m in export earnings each year. So the industry is very significant. Not only is it significant but it is also highly efficient in some States, particularly Victoria and Tasmania. The industry in those two States is the second most efficient in the world, second only to New Zealand. Not many other Australian industries, if any, can claim this degree of comparative international efficiency.

What is even more remarkable is that this efficiency has been achieved despite a horrendous maze of regulations imposed by both State and Federal governments. I will come back to that point in a little more detail later. One example is that Victoria alone has specific pricing arrangements for no fewer than 331 milk products. In effect, so complicated are the overall regulatory controls on the dairy industry that we do not have a national dairy industry; rather we have seven separate industries-one in each of the six States plus an export industry for manufactured milk products.

It is this export industry which is the major problem, though not the only problem, facing the Australian dairy industry. It is, in the main, the subject of the Bills now before the Senate. Seventy-three per cent of all milk production in Australia goes into manufactured milk products, particularly butter and cheese. The remainder is consumed as liquid milk. A large proportion of these manufactured dairy products is exported and our exports face fierce and totally unfair competition in third markets from the massively subsidised exports of the European Economic Community. The total cost of EEC subsidies for dairy products is almost $6,000m per year. The Victorian dairy industry, because a very high proportion of its production is exported, is the main sufferer from these unfair trading practices of the EEC. The mountain of EEC subsidised dairy products has become so great that it outweighs Australia's dairy exports by 12 times. It is essentially for this reason that Australia has the problem of considerable over-production of milk. We produce more milk than we can find a profitable market for.

Over the past 10 to 20 years the Australian dairy industry has undergone a massive rationalisation in an attempt to cope with the oversupply problem. No other Australian industry has proceeded so far with rationalisation. In the past 20 years the number of dairy farms has been reduced from about 50,000 to fewer than 20,000. In the last 10 years alone the number of dairy factories has been reduced by one-third. The industry has demonstrated beyond any doubt whatsoever the courage to undergo massive rationalisation. However, the problem of oversupply remains. The industry recognises and accepts this fact, and it therefore accepts the major thrusts of the dairy industry Bills we are now debating. Those thrusts are two fold; firstly, to further reduce milk production in Australia and, secondly, to remove and alter some of those regulatory measures which have prevented dairy producers from receiving appropriate market signals which will give them a proper guide as to the directions in which they should be moving, both in terms of the total volume of milk and the most profitable mix of products.

So there is no dispute between the Government, the Opposition or the industry over these objectives. There is also general agreement between the Government, the Opposition and the industry that there should be a levy on all milk produced to support the export prices from the corrupted and distorted world market to the level of some 30 per cent above export market prices. There is agreement that the tariffs on imported dairy products should be reviewed; that the Australian Dairy Corporation should have improved access to finance for the marketing of dairy products; and that there is a need for appropriate underwriting provisions. They are all areas of agreement between the Government, the Opposition and the industry.

However, there is considerable and totally justified dispute over the manner in which this Hawke Labor Government and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in particular have treated the dairy industry in their approach to the problems facing the industry. There is also grave and totally warranted concern about the dangerous and disruptive speed with which the Labor Government is forcing the industry to undertake the next major phase of its rationalisation program. The manner of approach towards the dairy industry by this Government can be described only as deplorable. It is brutal, truculent and totally insensitive. Not only that, but also the Hawke Labor Government and the Cain Labor Government in my own State have shown, I believe, a degree of deceit and dishonesty in their dealings with the dairy industry and the electorate that defy accepted codes of political decency. I will illustrate that harsh condemnation with two examples. On 12 November 1984, only three weeks before the Federal election, the Minister for Primary Industry released a statement which said, inter alia:
I have not moved away from the levy entitlement plan negotiated between me and the Australian Dairy Industry Conference and supported by the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation.

On 28 February 1985, two days before the Victorian election, the Victorian Labor Premier, Mr Cain, claimed that he had obtained agreement to a plan for the dairy industry, supported by the industry, the Federal Government and the six State governments. This claim by Mr Cain probably won him the State election. Two days after the State election, the Federal Minister for Primary Industry announced that the Federal Government rejected this plan. Rarely, if ever, in Australian political history has a government, and in this case two governments, both Labor, perpetrated such a wilful deceit on an industry or on an entire electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —A cynical political exercise.

—It certainly was. The new plan for the dairy industry which the Hawke Government eventually came up with in March contains a number of extraordinarily harsh provisions. The Government, when the Bills were debated in the other place, was almost totally intransigent on these provisions and it has refused to budge. I find it difficult to understand the reasons for this intransigence. The provisions to which the Opposition and the industry so strongly object do not go to the heart of the Government's proposals. As I said earlier, both the Opposition and the industry support the general thrust of these proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: The objectionable provisions relate only to the timing of the implementation of some, not all, of the Government's plan. There are two areas in which we believe the timing which will be imposed by the Government is far too harsh and draconian. The changes which will be imposed on the industry have far-reaching economic and financial implications for whole communities and they have also enormous potential social implications. The dairy industry and the communities dependent on the industry are not looking for relief from these changes. All they are asking for is a little more time in which to carry out the transition process.

The Government is saying that most of the changes must come about on 1 July 1985. The industry and the Opposition say that this period, of only another five weeks, is too short in respect of some of the provisions and that the adjustment time span should be lengthened by up to a couple of years. The Opposition is pressing for a slightly lengthened time span in only two areas. The first area is to extend the existing export pooling arrangements for butter and cheese by two years, to apply from 30 June 1987, instead of 30 June 1985 as proposed by the Government. The second area is to maintain current domestic prices for two years instead of the one year as decided by the Government. There is a third amendment that the Opposition is proposing, which I will briefly mention later.

The Opposition's amendment to extend the existing export pooling arrangements for butter and cheese for two years would give the industry time to adjust and respond to the changeover during the next six to 12 months. It is not just dairy farmers who will be affected, but also dairy factory employees, particularly in the co-operative dairy factories in Victoria and Tasmania. Without this two-year extension the industry will suffer enormous and totally unnecessary upheaval and hardship. If the pooling is taken away immediately, the Australian Dairy Corporation, which currently funds advance payments to manufacturers of up to 90 per cent of the underwritten product value, could well be forced immediately to reduce its lending from 90 per cent of the product value to as low as 50 per cent of a more conservative valuation of that produce. This, in turn, would reduce significantly the first advance payments to farmers.

Quite frankly, although neither the industry nor the Opposition wishes to oppose the nature of this change, we believe it is nothing short of brutal to introduce it with such savage speed. The pooling arrangements have been in operation for 50 years. The whole industry has been built around these Government imposed arrangements. There seems to me to be no valid reason whatsoever for terminating them with such brutal rapidity, rather than to do so in two years time, thereby giving the industry some breathing space in which to adjust. It is important to note that the Industries Assistance Commission, in its report of March 1984 on the dairy industry, agreed with this view of the Opposition. The Government has chosen callously to ignore the IAC recommendation.

The second amendment of a timing nature which the Opposition will move is to maintain current domestic prices for two years. The Government's proposal is for only one year, after which domestic prices would be phased down to a level 30 per cent above the export price. Under the Government proposal, assuming that market milk prices and the level of milk production for the next year or so remain unchanged, levies on butter and cheese will drop by an estimated 50 per cent in 1986-87. The Government's proposal fails to recognise that a large proportion of dairy products manufactured in one year are not sold until the following year. By extending the existing support levels for two years rather than one year, dairy production would be covered for around 18 months rather than the six months which would be the case under the Government's proposal. The two-year extension seems much fairer than the Government's proposal. It takes account of the nature of the industry, including the fact that it takes time to reduce herd numbers where breeding programs are based on a cycle of about two and a half years and the inescapable average six-month lag between the production and the sale of dairy products. The amendment that the Opposition proposes would leave the industry in exactly the same position in five years time in relation to domestic prices as would the Government's plan. The big difference is that our amendment would give the industry a little more time to make its initial adjustments and would provide a simpler and more predictable mechanism to reduce production levies over the period. It would therefore permit better business planning by the industry and would be less socially and economically disruptive in the short term.

If the Government's proposals on export pooling and domestic price support levels are adopted without the amendments that the Opposition proposes to move, the regrettable result will be that, although rationalisation of the industry will occur, it will be the younger and most efficient producers, particularly in Victoria and Tasmania, and not the least efficient producers, who will be forced out of the industry. Surely that cannot be the Government's intention.

The third amendment that the Opposition will move does not relate to timing. Rather, it relates to the method of establishing market support payments. Without going into the technical detail, the effect of the Government's proposals in this respect will be to distort the market as between dairy products by giving greater market support to whole milk powder than to butter and cheese. This would cause levy funds collected from farmers to be transferred to the two large dairy product producers, Nestle Australia Ltd and Unigate Australia Pty Ltd. The amount involved could be some $5m per annum. The Opposition believes that this in an inequitable anomaly and we propose a simple amendment to overcome the distortion.

It is also worth noting that the three problem areas we see in the Government's plan for the dairying industry go beyond that industry; in particular, as Senator Brownhill mentioned earlier, the Australian oilseeds industry is also concerned because of the disruptive effects that the timing of implementation of the plan will have on the margarine industry. It is also important to recognise that the problems confronting the dairying industry in Australia go well beyond the problems with which these Bills are concerned. Most of those other problems lie squarely at the feet of State governments.

I mentioned earlier that, with respect to the domestic market in Australia, there are really six separate dairying industries, one in each State. Each State has cosseted, shackled and inhibited its dairying industry with a positively mind-boggling array of regulatory controls. I mentioned that in my State of Victoria there are 331 milk products subject to separate pricing arrangements. These arrangements have not assisted the industry. On the contrary, they have compounded the industry's problems over and above the problems caused on the export markets by EEC dumping. The lack of flexibility in pricing imposed by the Victorian Government inhibits the highly efficient Victorian dairying industry from competing in its own market and in interstate markets.

However, the other major internal problem for the industry is the present restraints which exist on interstate trade in milk. Part of this restraint has arisen from the Dairy Industry Assistance Act and the Dairy Industry Assistance Levy Act which the previous Federal Government enacted in 1977. These Acts were never proclaimed but there is no doubt that their very existence has been seen by the dairying industry as inhibiting interstate trade in milk. The Opposition welcomes the Government's intention to repeal those Acts. But this action will not by itself open up interstate trading. That will require action by State governments, which have the responsibility for the regulation of the market milk sector.

It is essential that State governments, and most of all the Victorian Government, take steps to remove their plethora of regulations over the dairy industry to make it a truly national industry. The present situation is totally unacceptable for both producers and consumers alike. The Cain Government in Victoria has shown no signs of taking any initiative to resolve this situation. Indeed, it appears to have enshrined price fixing arrangements in its latest Act relating to the dairy industry. If that is the case, it should stand condemned by every dairy farmer in Victoria.

To return to the Bills, I summarise by saying that the Opposition, like the dairying industry, is in agreement with the overall objectives of this legislation. However, we condemn the Government for the manner in which it has treated the dairying industry in the long negotiations and the way in which it was so deceitfully dishonest not only with the industry but also with the electorate before both the last Federal election and the Victorian State election. We also consider that the Government is planning to implement several of its proposals with totally indecent haste, which is both brutal and unnecessary. It is a pace which ignores the fundamental practical realities of the industry. It is a pace which will cause massive economic and social dislocation, particularly in Victoria.

All members of this Labor Government who claim to be representative of rural electorates should hang their heads in shame at the social and economic hardship which the timing of the implementation of the Government's legislation will cause. I urge Government senators to remove this quite unnecessary hardship by supporting he Opposition's amendments. I welcome the decision by the Australian Democrats to do so. I believe honourable senators on both sides of the chamber must have been appalled at the truculence of Senator Walsh in his outburst in this place yesterday when he attempted to blackmail Opposition and Democrat senators into supporting the Government's proposals without any amendments. Not only did he demean himself and the Government; he demeaned the Senate. For that he, and through him the Government, will stand condemned by the Australian electorate.

Finally, I wish to record publicly my tribute to certain people and organisations that have worked so hard, so patiently and in such a willing spirit of negotiation over many months to reach a satisfactory negotiated compromise over these difficult issues. I particularly mention the representatives of the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation, the Australian Dairy Industry Conference and the United Dairy farmers of Victoria. I also pay great tribute to my colleague Mr Ralph Hunt, to the members of the Opposition's primary industry committee and especially its Chairman, Mr Peter Drummond, and to several of my Liberal Party Senate colleagues, notably Senators Archer, Lewis and Watson.

Given the Minister's view that the introduction of such a tax without agreement on discounting would be 'quite catastrophic'-Senator Walsh's words-does this restatement of the union movement's opposition effectively end the prospect of a broad-based consumption tax, particularly as it comes only 24 hours after the Treasurer spent a day with members of the Australian Council of Trade Unions Executive putting his case and answering their concerns?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did see reports of what Mr Dolan has said. He has a view. As far as I am aware, the ACTU does not have an official view at this stage. The more relevant question for the Government is: What will the Government's policy be if that situation arises? It had been made very clear by various Government members that the Government would argue that, if there is to be a broader-based or deeper consumption tax which significantly increases the CPI, that CPI increase should not flow through into wages.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister, in his answer, attributed Mr Dolan's views to his speaking in a personal capacity. Mr Dolan is reported to have said that it is the ACTU which has clearly stated its opposition. I ask the Minister: Is he in a position to confirm whether Mr Dolan was speaking in a personal capacity or as President of the ACTU? Is he denying that the ACTU view is as presented by Mr Dolan?

—I apologise. I read the report quickly. I did not realise that Mr Dolan was claiming to speak officially on behalf of the ACTU. Assuming that report is correct, I do not really know whether the ACTU has made a formal decision on this matter or not.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of an article which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on 9 May 1985 which reports on comments made by Mr Ian Temby, QC, Director of Public Prosecutions, that it could take 10 years or more to complete legal action against bottom of the harbour tax schemes? Is it true that only one person has been convicted for bottom of the harbour offences? Has the tax avoidance legislation so far enacted been an effective mechanism in recouping lost taxation revenue? If not, will this revenue shortfall cause budgetary problems?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the Press report to which Senator Richardson refers. It is out of context or, probably more accurately, incomplete. In reply to a question, Mr Temby said:

ANSWER.PARA: It could well be that the last bottom of the harbour case will not be finished until 10 years hence if every person criminally involved to any extent was prosecuted.

The latter part of that statement was not reported. It is not correct to say that only one person has been convicted. As of now there have been two convictions, of Messrs Faint and Hurley, who were each sentenced to two years imprisonment. There will, however, be cases running for some time. Committals currently are a minimum of three months. Some may be as long as 18 months. There are delays in cases being listed due to normal court delays. The trials are lengthy and complex. Inevitably, there will be appeals and procedural sidetracks; for example, reviews under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. Also proceedings are anticipated to restrict extraditions from one State to another. Over 50 people have been charged with bottom of the harbour offences. The investigation of a number of others is continuing.

In regard to the last part of Senator Richardson's question, as to whether tax avoidance legislation so far enacted has been an effective mechanism in recouping lost tax revenue, the answer would have to be no, it has not been completely effective because the Senate insists on rejecting the legislation that would make it completely effective. Indeed, half the Senate continues to express the view that if somebody has had his fist in the till all the week, and he is caught with his fist in the till on Friday, he has to give back what he pinched on Friday but he does not have to give back what he pinched on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday. That is the view of half the Senate. It is not the view of the Government. The view of the Government is that he should have to pay it back no matter when he pinched it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer to the appalling circumstances surrounding the death of a three-year-old girl in Melbourne this week after she had been put on a water diet for four weeks. Is the Minister aware of the grave concern expressed by police about the total breakdown in community services in relation to this case? At the Attorney-General's next joint meeting with State Attorneys-General will he raise this issue with a view to ensuring that laws relevant to situations like this are uniform throughout the Commonwealth and are stringent enough to avoid a repetition of this tragic case?

—I will, of course, pass on Senator Chipp's concern about this matter, which I am sure represents and reflects the concern of many other honourable senators in this place, to the Attorney-General. As Senator Chipp acknowledges, this is a matter in the first instance for State law and not something as to which the Commonwealth can do more than encourage the implementation of effective law around the rest of the country, perhaps by way of not only encouraging uniform laws but also setting an example here in the Australian Capital Territory. In that respect I mention that the Law Reform Commission did prepare a report some little time ago on child welfare, an excellent report, which was presented to the previous Government and which contains very valuable discussion of the problem of neglected children, including the question of children in the care of medical treatment. The Government is still studying that report with a view to its implementation in the Australian Capital Territory. That, in conjunction with the recently released Carney report in Victoria, also dealing with child welfare matters, suggests that there is now a solid basis of research and recommendation on which appropriate laws and procedures can be built, to the extent that there are inadequacies in existing law and practice.

—Is the Minister for Finance aware of a call by the honourable member for the Northern Territory, in his capacity as shadow Minister for northern development and local government, for the establishment of a new State of north Queensland? Can the Minister inform the House of the cost of the honourable member's proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the first half of the question, I am aware that the honourable member for the Northern Territory, in speeches in Innisfail and Townsville, called for the establishment of a new State. Indeed he said:

ANSWER.PARA: There is no reason at all why there must always be a six State Australia. The Northern Territory will make it seven and eight or nine would do just as well, probably better.

He also called for full representation in the Senate for the new State as well as full representation in the Senate for the Northern Territory. That, of course, has quite significant cost implications by itself. If the Northern Territory were to have a full representation of 12 senators and if there were to be 12 senators from one or two extra new States created in northern Queensland there would be an increase of something like 100 politicians. I am not sure off the top of my head what the cost of that would be, but it would certainly run into many millions of dollars. The total cost of the package of that number of politicians with office equipment, staff and everything else, would be of the order of $22m.

If the Northern Territory is an indication of the bureaucracy required to run the proposed State or States, there would need to be about an additional 14,000 public servants and that would cost in the order of $400m. If the area to be encompassed by the proposed State were the area north of the Tropic of Capricorn which has about one million people or six to seven times the population of the Northern Territory-the Northern Territory receives some $700m-odd of Commonwealth funds, which is more than four times the national average-and if the new State or States of north Queensland were to be formed and if they were to run governments as extravagant as that run by the honourable member for the Northern Territory when he was Chief Minister, and on the same basis, the additional cost to the Commonwealth Budget would be of the order of $3 billion to $4 billion. Perhaps one of the most extraordinary things of all in the speech of the honourable member for the Northern Territory was this:
North Queensland needs to by-pass Brisbane, removing what is effectively an unnecessary level of decision making between the north and the realisation of its aspirations.

That gives us a hint as to what Mr Everingham thinks of the Premier of Queensland. Since Mr Everingham is the spokesman for northern development and local government on behalf of the Liberal Party of Australia, I cannot say whether he was speaking officially on behalf of the Liberal Party and whether we should expect that the Liberal Party will officially incorporate into its policy establishment of one or two new States in north Queensland with the consequential increased expenditure which that would generate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to be serious and ask the Minister for Finance a question which follows Senator Chaney's question in a further attempt to elucidate something from this Government in relation to one of the most important questions facing Australia. The Minister will no doubt recall that in answer to a question from me on 7 May, and in dismissing the views of Mr Joe Thompson about union opposition to discounting the consumer price index for the effects of a consumption tax, he warned that in the absence of discounting a feedback into wages could sustain a very much higher level of inflation and he said that views of significant people in the trade union movement on discounting were 'terribly important'. I emphasise the words 'terribly important'. Is the Minister aware that, in restating the opposition of the Australian Council of Trade Unions to discounting, Mr Cliff Dolan, the President of the ACTU, said yesterday: 'It may be a question of accepting somewhat higher inflation than the Government is expecting over the next two years'? Is the Minister concerned at this view or does he still consider that Mr Dolan's opinions are not relevant to the tax debate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am again flattered that the members of the Opposition are such avid readers of my answers to questions. They are apparently titillated by them. I think it is unarguable that if a one-off increase in the CPI was fed back into wages inflation would be higher than it would otherwise have been. When I answered that question on 7 May it was put in the context, if I remember correctly, of an increase in the CPI caused by one-off indirect tax changes of the order of 7 per cent. There is no dispute at all that if one-off increases in the CPI caused only by a change in the taxation system of that magnitude were to be fed back into wages, there would be a substantially higher rate of inflation than would otherwise have been.

ANSWER.PARA: As for Mr Dolan's comments, the ACTU is coming along to participate in the tax summit. Senator Rae's Leader could also participate in it if he had chosen to do so, but of course he chose not to do so. Therefore one must conclude that he has no views worth putting to the tax summit, which would not surprise many people anyway. I suggest that Senator Rae display a bit of patience and wait until the summit has been held. He will get a better indication of what the ACTU's position is after it has considered the questions and options and so on that are put forward, and the information provided. The Government will make a decision some time after that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister answer the final part of my question, which was: Is the Minister concerned at the view, or does he still consider that Mr Dolan's opinions are not relevant to the tax debate?
—The attitude that the Australian Council of Trade Unions finally adopts on this question will of course be important.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave, Mr President, to ask a question of the Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, Senator Georges.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to a newspaper article which reports that a Sydney man is organising Australia's first bullfight, at Adelaide in November this year. Has the Select Committee on Animal Welfare had the opportunity to look at this proposal? If not, is it possible that the Committee may be looking at this or similar proposals in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President-

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! This is Senator Georges's first answer to a question. He shall be heard in silence.

—Yes, the article concerned has been drawn to the Committee's attention, together with a number of other incidents that have occurred which are of very great concern to the Committee, such as the destruction of wallaby populations in Tasmania by the use of the chemical 1080, the organised deer hunting for the tourist trade in the northern part of Queensland, and the organised pigeon shooting in the streets of Rockhampton in the early hours of the morning. All these matters are a grave reflection on the activity of humans in regard to animals. One can only say that humans do not show up well. The particular matter to which Senator Colston has referred is a startling commentary on human attitudes. It is said in the statement that the ears and tail of the bull will be awarded to the winner of the grand prix that is to take place in Adelaide. If I might say so, other areas of more substantial contact with animals, especially in the field of animal experimentation, leave very much to be desired.

ANSWER.PARA: We will be making a report to the Senate on the progress of the Committee. We will have in mind the investigation of these incidents. I notice that the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals in Adelaide is in a position to do something about this matter. Possibly it can be more effective than the Committee. I hope it will take the matter in hand. Finally, if one were to consider the animals and the humans together, one could always ask: Who are the brutes?

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Finance agree with his colleague, Dr Andrew Theophanous, who said on AM this week that working people had borne a disproportionate share of the economic burden in recent times? Given the Prime Minister's view that Australians have been living beyond their means, does the Minister believe that the interests of longer term economic recovery require a reduction in the real level of wages?

—I did not hear the statement of Andrew Theophanous, but I was asked whether I agreed with his statement that in recent times ordinary working people have borne a disproportionate share, or words to that effect, of the burdens on this society. If applied to the period of the last Liberal Government at least, that is undeniably true, because ordinary working people, honest wage and salary earners, were paying their taxes, and other people were not paying their taxes because they were sinking their companies to the bottom of the harbour, particularly in Perth. Given that Senator Knowles was an official of the Liberal Party of Western Australia at the time when more than half the members of the Liberal Party's finance committee were ultimately shown to have been directors of companies which had sunk their companies to the bottom of the harbour, she should, presumably, have had some rather intimate knowledge of the way assorted people were failing to pay the taxes which they ought to have paid, through sinking their companies with their profits to the bottom of the harbour. Because of those actions-

—Mr President, I take a point of order. I know that, as usual, you will have been listening with a great deal of care to Senator Walsh's discursive response to Senator Knowles's question. I put it to you, Mr President, with respect, that on two occasions Senator Walsh has sought to cast reflections upon Senator Knowles, contrary to Standing Orders.

—I have listened carefully to the remarks of Senator Walsh. There is no point of order in the point taken by Senator Crichton-Browne. But I ask the Minister to try to restrict his answer to the questions asked by Senator Knowles without getting into the realm of debate.

—Certainly, Mr President. If I was debating the question, I apologise. I thought I was just answering the question whether in recent times ordinary working people have been ripped off and exploited by others. The answer to that, unquestionably, is yes. I was just citing one example of the ways they were ripped off-that half the members of the Liberal Party finance committee in Western Australia sunk their companies to the bottom of the harbour to avoid their taxation responsibilities, and Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Knowles were senior officials of the Liberal Party at the time all that happened. They ought to have known about it, without asking me.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is he aware that the minority Queensland Government had deliberately planned this week's raids on two fertility control clinics for over 12 months, with the ulterior motive of launching yet another devious attack on the Hawke Labor Government by seizing Medicare documentation as well as private medical records? What rights does the Federal Government have in relation to the protection of confidentiality of Medicare documentation? Can the Minister take action to have Medicare records returned immediately and will he put in place procedures which will prevent any future blatant breach of confidentiality by the irresponsible Queensland minority Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read the Press reports of the raids on the fertility control clinics in Queensland by the Queensland Government, but I did not note that they had been planned for about 12 months. Senator Reynolds has apparently seen a statement to that effect and therefore infers that the Queensland Government had an ulterior motive, a conspiratorial motive, in doing this because it seized Medicare records during the raid. The only comment I would make on imputing that motive to the Queensland Government is that there is an old saying around here: 'If you have the choice between a conspiracy and a stuff-up when you are talking about the Queensland Government, you can back it in that it is the latter'.

ANSWER.PARA: I agree that it seems extraordinary that the Queensland Police, in seizing the records which they took, chose also to take the Medicare documentation. I, too, have grave doubts about the motives of the Queensland Police and the raid in general. I suppose that if the police feel that they need evidence to prosecute people for the alleged offences, as they claim, they may take medical records although most of us would be concerned about that. For instance, there are strict rules in the Australian Federal Police about the use of such medical records and their storage. Medicare records are supposed to be protected by Commonwealth legislation.

It is very difficult to understand of what use Medicare records would be in such a prosecution. If the aim of the Queensland Government, through its police, is to disrupt Medicare in Queensland by this seizing of Medicare records, it will not succeed, because the Medicare system has an inbuilt capacity to cope with the loss of large numbers of records such as that. If those records have been illegally seized, I certainly believe that the Minister for Health should do and will be doing something about it. I will refer these specific matters to the Minister for Health and get an early reply for Senator Reynolds.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce of part of an answer to a question yesterday in which he said, amongst other things:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government's clear disposition is not to discount the effects of the devaluation at the September quarter hearing.

Is the Minister aware of the information contained in the most recent Business Council of Australia bulletin on the effects of devaluation? I ask the Minister whether he agrees with the following statement:

The devaluation will increase the rate of inflation by at least several percentage points before the year is out, and that some of these effects will be included in the CPI index used for the September national wage case.

Will the Minister now assure the Senate that, if the Business Council prediction is correct, the Government will not support a full flow-on of the consumer price index but will discount for the effects of the devaluation?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said on a number of occasions in the Senate-I had better say it again because I still get these sorts of questions-that the role of the Commonwealth Government in relation to the wage case later this year will be to put a submission to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on the Government's view. As I said yesterday, the Government's predilection-I used terminology such as that-was not to argue that the effects of the devaluation be discounted in that case. The reason I have expressed that view on a number of occasions is that the Government does not feel that the CPI effects in the September quarter will be very significant. If I may say so, that is a marginally different approach from that suggested in the Business Council newsletter that Senator Scott quoted from. I take it no further than to say that before the Government makes a submission to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission it will make up its mind bearing those factors in mind.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN SECURITY INTELLIGENCE ORGANISATION: PROPOSED PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Attorney-General seen the reported comments of the Leader of the Opposition about the Opposition's attitude towards the establishment of a joint parliamentary committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation? Mr Peacock was reported as describing the proposed committee as a 'security risk' and a 'limit on ASIO's operational efficiency'. Can the Minister outline the purpose of the committee? Does he see any justification in the opposition to the setting up of the committee and the Opposition's promise to abolish it if ever returned to government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For a number of years the Australian Labor Party has been arguing for the existence of a parliamentary committee on security as a desirable element in an overall accountability structure in relation to a major security agency. I guess it would in a sense have been surprising if the Government had done other than indicate an intention to proceed with that structure. Certainly, the views of Mr Justice Hope on the necessity of such a body in the Australian context as compared, for example, with the United States of America were weighed very carefully by the Government in coming to its decision. But, on balance, we believe, as the Prime Minister said yesterday, that a further improvement in the accountability of ASIO and the security community can be obtained by directly involving the Parliament, on both sides and in both Houses, in imposing the extra discipline of some degree of external scrutiny of that intelligence community.

ANSWER.PARA: The precise functions of the committee will be defined in part of a legislative package to be brought forward in the Budget session, at which time more detailed questions on the structure and mode of operation of the committee will also be addressed, as Senator Button said in answer to an earlier question. Certainly I can again say, as did the Prime Minister yesterday, that the Government is fully aware of the need to protect sensitive security information. We believe that appropriate arrangements can be made to ensure that a small but well informed parliamentary committee can operate effectively in the public interest.

It is really extraordinary, against that background, that the Opposition Leader reacted as he did. Such a committee will obviously contribute to a better-informed, bipartisan approach to security matters, which one would have thought would have appealed very much to the Opposition. In our parliamentary democracy, the Executive, in all its manifestations, is ultimately accountable to the Parliament. I express surprise that the Leader of the Opposition questions the more effective exercise of that responsibility in the way that is proposed. I note that there is an inconsistency of approach to the extent that, having huffed and puffed as he has, the Opposition Leader has nonetheless said that the Opposition would participate in such a committee. Generally speaking, I say on behalf of the Government that the reaction of Mr Peacock was entirely lacking in principle, in sense or in statesmanship and entirely justifies the description of him that was given by the Treasurer in the House of Representatives yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Finance, follows his answer to the question asked by Senator Richardson. The Minister suggested in his answer that the previous Government's bottom of the harbour legislation had not been successful. I ask the Minister on what he bases that comment. Can he tell the Senate how much has been recovered under that legislation and to what extent the estimates of what would be recovered have been met and satisfied? Can he give any other reasons for his saying that the legislation as passed has not achieved its objectives?

—Senator Chaney has misconstrued the answer I gave. I did not say that the previous Government's legislation was not being successfully applied. As far as I know, it is. But that was not the question. The question was: 'Has the legislation so far enacted been effective in recouping lost taxation revenue?'. The answer to that is no, it has not been, because the legislation enacted is inadequate. The legislation enacted so far, with one exception which I will mention soon, recovers the company tax which would have been payable had companies not been sunk to the bottom of the harbour. The one exception, of course, is clause 3 (12) of the relevant Bill, which exempted from liability shareholders in companies sold to bottom of the harbour operators but who had subsequently attempted a failed tax avoidance scheme before sinking those companies to the bottom of the harbour. No sensible attempt was made at any stage to present a case for allowing that exception. The legislation already passed recovers only part of the tax which had been avoided or evaded, because as well as the tax on those companies exempted by clause 3 (12), which I have already mentioned-
—Do you know how much has been recovered?

—I do not know. I will get an answer for the honourable senator. Nobody was obliged to pay tax under the previous Government's legislation on the deemed dividend payments. That is, when the companies were sunk, not only did these current year profits escape from the net but also profits from previous years, which sooner or later would have been required to be distributed to shareholders, disappeared to the bottom of the harbour. This Government has attempted to recover the personal tax which would have been payable had companies not been sunk to the bottom of the harbour as well as the tax that would have been payable had the clause 3 (12) exemption not been inserted for reasons which remain to this day a matter for wide-eyed conjecture.

—I direct my question to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. On 15 May 1985 in answer to my question on Lebanon the Minister advised that he had requested the Australian permanent representative in New York to explore the scope for constructive action in the United Nations Security Council. Can the Minister advise what steps have been taken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said on 15 May that I was asking the Australian permanent representative in New York to explore, as Senator Sibraa has put it, with the representative of Lebanon the scope for constructive action in the Security Council on the problems of Lebanon. The permanent representative has now held discussions with his Lebanese counterpart and with a senior member of the United Nations Secretariat. Also our Ambassador to Lebanon has called on the Secretary-General of the Lebanese Foreign Ministry.

ANSWER.PARA: The Lebanese representatives expressed appreciation for Australia's interest and willingness to help. The Secretary-General of the Lebanese Foreign Ministry outlined Lebanon's views on possible United Nations action. He said that the first step was to implement Security Council resolution 425. This resolution called for the withdrawal of Israeli forces from Lebanon and established the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon, UNIFIL, to confirm Israel's withdrawal, restore peace and assist the Lebanese Government to re-establish its authority.

The Lebanese authorities therefore would not favour action in the Security Council until Israeli forces had withdrawn from Lebanese territory. The Israeli withdrawal is expected to be completed early in June, after which we would urge that the Security Council consider the situation. Australia would participate actively in such consideration. We would emphasise the deep concern of the Government and people over the grave situation in Lebanon and seek constructive action by the Council.

I have asked our permanent representative in New York to call on the Secretary-General of the United Nations to discuss the scope for action in the Council and by the Secretary-General to promote the cause of peace in Lebanon.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL FAR WEST CHILDREN'S HEALTH SCHEME

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services. In answer to a question in the Senate on 10 May the Minister indicated that he was aware of allegations made in November 1983 concerning the safety of children resident at the Manly complex of the Royal Far West Children's Health Scheme. Can the Minister say whether those allegations concerned, among other things, the sexual assault of younger children by older children and whether the matter was referred to the New South Wales Crown Solicitor? Has an independent inquiry been ordered into the Royal Far West Children's Health Scheme? If one has, can the Minister say, first, what conclusions the inquiry reached; secondly, what recommendations it made; thirdly, what action is likely to be taken, when and by whom; and, finally, whether the Council of the Royal Far West Children's Health Scheme is able to censor or ignore all or any of the recommendations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Haines has said, I answered a question, from Senator Sibraa, on 10 May about the Royal Far West Children's Health Scheme. I think I said at the time that I was aware of complaints made about the operation of that scheme. I was also aware of, and in fact have recently received, the reports of two inquiries into that Scheme-one by Professor John Beveridge, the Professor of Pediatrics at the University of New South Wales; and another by a paediatrician and I believe an official of the New South Wales Health Department.

ANSWER.PARA: The question of the Royal Far West Children's Health Scheme involves the Commonwealth, as Senator Haines probably knows, because it funds that institution in Manly as a nursing home to the extent of some $2m a year. The New South Wales State Government also provides funds through the Department of Health and runs a special school at the institution. Therefore both governments are involved.

There are three types of complaint. The first type, mentioned by Senator Haines, concerns allegations of misconduct and sexual assault of occupants of the home at the time; the second type relates to the efficiency and efficacy of the service; and the third type involves the appropriateness of such a service in this day and age.

Mr Mulock, the Minister for Health in New South Wales, is primarily involved in regard to the first type of complaint as his Department is the licensing authority, although obviously we are concerned. The second type of complaint, the efficiency of the service, involves both the Federal and State departments. The third type, the appropriateness of such a service in this day and age when paediatricians and other specialists are readily available in all New South Wales country towns, is primarily a matter for the Federal Government in light of its very large funding.

I have had a brief conversation with Mr Mulock about the matter and the Secretary to my Department has had one meeting with the Secretary to the Department of Health in New South Wales. I am about to discuss with Mr Mulock and the heads of both departments the appropriate steps to take from here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does there seem to be substance to the complaints?

—I am not willing to make a judgment of that type. What I do know is that the Council of the Royal Far West Children's Health Scheme is concerned about at least one of the reports. There have been discussions between the Department of Health in New South Wales and the Council as to what action should be taken.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I take the view that the questions raised on all three levels are serious ones. They are serious not only for the children who use that service and their families but also for the Federal Government because of its considerable funding of the Scheme. I intend to finalise very quickly the appropriate action which I think should be taken and see whether the New South Wales Government and the Federal Government cannot take action which will sort out this problem to the satisfaction of both governments and in particular to the satisfaction of the community of New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport relates to the fact that unleaded petrol will be available in Australia shortly. When will unleaded petrol be available to the motoring public, and in what quantities? What percentage of cars and other vehicles currently available for purchase in Australia are equipped to take unleaded petrol in safety? What are the dangers of unleaded petrol being used in conventional vehicles? What would be the environmental advantages of the universal use of unleaded petrol in vehicles constructed to handle it with safety?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Transport and seek a reply.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security to the mini-Budget proposal to eliminate the family allowance for dependent student children over 18 years and the effect this decision will have on families. Where there are three or more children in a family and the older children cease to attract family allowance, will the reduction of family allowance be at the lower rate payable to the first and second child or will the mother lose the family allowance at the higher rate payable for the third and subsequent children?
—I must admit that I have forgotten. I will obtain that information as soon as possible, either out of the notes I have or from the Minister, and will let the honourable senator know.

—Has the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs seen the report in the Sydney Morning Herald of 4 May quoting the Aerospace Daily which claims that Israel has deployed a number of nuclear-armed Jericho 2 missiles in the Negev Desert and the Golan Heights? Can the Minister confirm this report? What implications for stability in the Middle East would such nuclear-armed missiles represent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of recent reports alleging that Israel has deployed a number of intermediate range nuclear missiles in the Negev Desert and the Golan Heights. The Government is not in a position at this stage to comment on these reports, but certainly it is concerned about the possible effects such reports might have on the stability of the region.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's policy on the proliferation of nuclear weapons is very well known. It is our firm view that the only way to avoid the increase of additional suspicions and tensions arising from the existence of unsafeguarded nuclear facilities is for those countries involved to place those facilities under international safeguards. The acceptance of binding non-proliferation commitments such as those embodied in the Treaty on the Non-Profileration of Nuclear Weapons would do much to reassure countries in the region and the international community of the peaceful intent of nuclear programs. I will take Senator Childs's question on notice and give him such further information as I can in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and refers to shipping freight rates. I refer to the Minister's Press release about the Government's decision to reject the Industries Assistance Commission interim report on fertilisers and the decision instead to continue the current arrangements for another 12 months pending the release of the final IAC report. Although it is not mentioned in the Minister's Press release, I ask the Minister: Is not one of the major problems in that industry the excessive freight rates of Australian flag shipping for the cartage of phosphate rock from Christmas Island? Are these rates not causing great difficulty for that industry and, indeed, for every Australian industry which is forced to ship on Australian flag ships? DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence I present a report on the Jackson report on Australia's overseas aid program dated May 1985, together with the transcripts of evidence and extracts from the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
1. This inquiry was first referred to the Committee in the previous Parliament by the Minister for Foreign Affairs on 7 June 1984 when he tabled the Jackson Report in the House of Representatives.

2. In tabling the report the Minister announced that there would be an opportunity to debate the major issues canvassed in the report and that this process would take about 12 months. The consequent debate in the community has indeed been vigorous and extensive, and has been assisted in no small measure by the willingness of members of the Jackson Committee, including its Chairman, Sir Gordon Jackson, to make themselves available to take part in it. As a result, the main issues addressed in the report have received the kind of thorough airing that an issue of the importance of Australia's aid activities deserves. The report of this Committee forms a part of that healthy process.

3. In addressing the reference made to it, the Committee decided to focus its attention on six broad areas which have dominated the public debate and which are at the heart of the Jackson recommendations. Those areas are: aid philosophy; the question of the relationship between trade and aid; aid to Papua New Guinea; the geographical distribution of aid; multilateral aid; and constraints on aid effectiveness, including the aid volume issue. As well, the Committee gave attention to several less broad but nonetheless highly important matters of significance to the Australian aid effort, including notably issues concerning women in the development process, the role of non-government organisations, and the future of development education.

4. All of these areas involve issues on which very firm, often very different, views are held by individuals and groups within the Australian community. The Committee, like the Jackson Committee itself, was left in no doubt of the sincerity with which these differing viewpoints were held, and all were vigorously advocated during our hearings. At the end of this process, however, and with some qualifications I refer to later, the Committee found itself in general agreement with the spirit and recommendations of the Jackson report. In this regard the Committee found it helpful to meet with Sir Gordon and some of the members of his committee on two occasions, in August last year and again in March of this year. On behalf of the members of the Committee I pay tribute to Sir Gordon Jackson and the other members of the review committee for their efforts.

5. The Jackson conclusion that the most effective contribution of aid lies in removing major constraints to development was endorsed by the Committee. A more sensitive and comprehensive mechanism of country programming within ADAB will help to ensure that the humanitarian purpose behind the giving of aid, which the Committee felt should be the paramount objective of aid programs, will be more effectively embodied in the overall Australian program.

6. The trade aid question dominated the public hearings of the Committee with a range of conflicting views being put to us. The Jackson Committee was against the use of aid as a subsidy mechanism for industry or as a substitute for industry policy. The Confederation of Australian Industry referred to the Jackson Committee's approach as one which abstracts itself from the real world, while some non-government organisations took the view that increased use of mechanisms such as the development import finance facility would not be a legitimate means of meeting aid objectives. The Committee's conclusion was generally to support the Jackson Committee approach, but it has suggested that ADAB improve its efforts to ensure that the business community is fully aware of the opportunities available to it under the aid program. The report points out some of those opportunities. In that connection and in response to a view pressed with the Committee by the business community in particular the report notes that if our aid to Papua New Guinea is excluded Australia has one of the most heavily tied bi-lateral programs in the world, and very little scope remains to increase the extent of tying, even if that were thought desirable. The Committee concluded that the value of the aid program to commercial interests can best be extended by careful selection and design of aid programs so as to emphasise areas in which Australia is competitive.

7. In regard to aid to Papua New Guinea, the Committee supports the Jackson proposal for a predictable and gradual reduction in Budget support accompanied by a move from that form of aid to project aid. The Jackson Committee suggested a 5 per cent decline in the level of budget support with a 3 per cent decline in the overall level of aid. The Committee considers that the Jackson recommendations should serve as the basis for our agreement with Papua New Guinea but that the rates of decline recommended by Jackson should be gradually accelerated.

8. Another important area of discussion on the Jackson Report has been the geographic focus recommended in it, and particularly as that affects aid to Africa. Jackson suggested four geographic categories for Australia's aid effort, and this Committee supports the general thrust of the Jackson recommendations aimed at rationalising the geographic distribution of our program and thus increasing the effectiveness of our overall aid effort. So far as Africa is concerned, the Committee recommended that Australia give very positive consideration to joining the African Development Bank at an early date. This would give Australia an enhanced and much more effective involvement in long-term project aid in Africa, where 26 of the world's 36 poorest countries are located, and would complement the continued Australian effort in all other areas of aid to Africa, which the Jackson report recommends and which the Committee supports. The Committee also suggested that membership of the Caribbean Development Bank be considered at a later stage should Australia develop particular expertise in the problems of small island states.

9. The Jackson Committee's findings on the management of aid delivery were commented on by the Minister when he tabled the report, he noted that it documents a sad history and points to considerable room for improvement. The Committee was informed that initiatives are underway to improve the resources and capabilities of ADAB. The Committee strongly supports the Jackson recommendations on aid management. It has recommended the establishment of an external review unit and an internal effectiveness review unit, their purpose being to monitor the implementation of the Jackson recommendations and (in the case of the former) to report annually on the Government's response to the report. The external review unit would be made up of individuals chosen from inter alia the business community, trade unions, non-government aid organisations, ADAB, the academic community and the Parliament.
10. The proposal that the head of ADAB be made a statutory officer was considered favourably by the Committee.

11. The Committee noted with disquiet the announcement by the Treasurer on 14 May 1985 that the forward estimates for the aid program had been reduced by $23.9m, and pointed to the likelihood that many of the Jackson recommendations which have attracted community support would have to be delayed or foregone unless available resources are increased.

12. In concluding, I would thank the members of the sub-committee who first considered the report and to the members of the main Committee whose expeditious consideration of it allowed it to be tabled here today. I would also thank the Director of ADAB, for seconding Mr Kerr-Stevens of his organisation to act as the adviser to the sub-committee. The secretariat, as I have come to expect, worked tirelessly and deserve much of the credit (but none of the blame) for this report.
Thank you Mr President.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

It gave me a good deal of pleasure to table the Official Report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Vietnam, Cambodia, Thailand and Laos. I do so on behalf of the delegation which it was my privilege to lead.

The visit was historic in that it was the first time an Australian Parliamentary Delegation had visited the Peoples Republic of Kampuchea, the nation which is still recognised in some areas as Cambodia. As indicated in the Report the Australian Government does not recognise either government in the country so we were welcomed as a delegation representing the Australian Parliament. The term 'welcomed' is carefully chosen as our reception could not have been more cordial.
I hasten to add that each of the other countries visited extended the same welcome and also spread no effort in attempting to make our visit worthwhile and at the same time enjoyable.

There are two difficulties facing any group which visits another on what we loosely call fact finding missions. The fact is that most people find it difficult to look or listen objectively despite the best of intentions. The other is that all countries, our own included, present to their guests those things they want them to see, for whatever reason. As a result visitors leave with a less than complete understanding and appreciation of the country and its people.

Conscious of these factors we decided in preparing our report to try and record what we were told and describe what we were shown. Where it was possible for us to verify claims made we have done so. Where there were different views put regarding the one incident we have recorded them. Where what was said did not appear to us to coincide with the situation as we observed it this has been noted. But we would wish to be seen as recorders rather than critics or apologists. We feel sure our hosts would appreciate and welcome such an approach.

May I once again pay tribute to those who contributed to the success of the tour: Our hosts in each of the countries and the officers, particularly the interpreters who provided sterling service. Officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs, those in Australia and particularly those in overseas missions who on the one hand provided background briefings and on the other extended personal friendship and assistance.
Our Secretary, Alan Hume for his unfailing good humour and constant support and other Parliamentary officers for their contributions.

Members of the delegation who at all times are worthy ambassadors for their country not forgetting the two wives whose inclusion in the group was most appreciated and whose contribution was significant.

I think it is fair to say that Australians generally know little of the area which we visited. It is our hope that the report will help in a small way to repair this situation and assist in building bridges between those countries and ourselves. I must apologise for the late presentation of the report. It is due in the main to the resignation from the Public Service shortly after our return of the delegation, the Secretary, Mr Alan Hume. His resignation I should note was not as a result of his trip. We also experienced delays in securing accurate statistics, for example only today I received late material which should be included in the report. May I suggest that on page 65 of your copy you amend the section dealing with the numbers of refugees coming to Australia to read:

''Up to June 1984, there was a total of 88,112 Indo-Chinese refugee arrivals in Australia, of which 26,223 had come from Thailand. Amongst the Indo-Chinese arrivals from Thailand, there were some 10,801 Kampucheans, most of whom would have come from camps along the Thai-Kampuchean border such as those visited by the Delegation. To this figure should be added Vietnamese ''Land'' people, for which it is difficult to obtain precise figures (in the period, 8,944 Vietnamese refugee arrivals came from Thailand, and this figure would have included both ''land'' and ''boat'' people).''
This amendment will present a fuller picture than that which is given by the present paragraph.

While every care has been taken to avoid errors the manner in which the final draft was prepared (in some haste to enable the report to be tabled before we rose) allows of the possibility. For this I apologise. I commend the report to the Senate and look forward to having it debated in due course.
