This is the final report of the Australian Egg Board, whose demise follows the repeal of the Egg Export Control Acts and the Egg Export Charges Acts as from 1 January this year. The Egg Board came into being to solve a perennial problem of all of Australia's primary industries-the problem of marketing a commodity where the overseas price is less than local production costs.

Australia's egg producers are among the most efficient in the world-that is, their cost of production is among the lowest in the world, and they use the most technically advanced production methods to minimise production costs. However, they export to countries which have very high tariff walls to protect and encourage their own inefficient producers. Such a country is Japan, which has been the major export market for Australia's eggs for the last decade, and was one of the markets to which Australia turned when the United Kingdom market was no longer available after the United Kingdom joined the European Economic Community. Australia also used to be a major exporter to the Middle East, until large increases in freight rates reduced our competitiveness.

The other major disability of Australian primary exports is competition in the face of dumping by overseas countries. These countries are prepared to get rid of their surpluses at any price. We have no such mechanism. The egg industry of Australia has not been affected by this problem, as its surplus for export has never represented more than 27 per cent of production, and is now more like 7.5 per cent. This has been because of the effective operation of the Egg Board. This low surplus of eggs has been achieved at a high cost to the egg industry in terms of restrictions on production, and has led to a secondary growth industry-that of trade in hen quotas-which will make it very traumatic for the industry if the present moves towards deregulation succeed. Many producers have invested heavily in buying quotas from other producers who have left the industry and these people stand to lose a considerable capital investment if the quotas are removed.

The other main exporters of eggs are Canada and South Africa, which have a national exporting body, and the United States of America, where individual producers sell their surpluses on the world market for whatever they can get. The latter model is probably the only long term self-adjusting production-export model. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: HUMAN RIGHTS AND THE MIGRATION ACT 1958

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I deplore part of one recommendation of the report of the Human Rights Commission on Human Rights and the Migration Act 1958, that of allowing into Australia, through the migration program, certain homosexuals. I believe that such a proposal will further erode traditional family relationships and the security of the family unit. It seems fashionable today to talk about the family but not about marriage. I believe that the contorted logic of the Human Rights Commission is based on a strong emphasis on the family in our migration policy and on the right to freedom of association. However, to accept the Commission's view that persons in permanent homosexual relationships are discriminated against in a way that is inconsistent with section 26 of the Racial Discrimination Act if they are not accorded the same rights of reunion as are married and de facto couples, I believe, is distasteful to all decent living Australians.

The emphasis today increasingly is on freedoms but not necessarily on community responsibilities. It is about time that the rights of the community at large were respected. To include people within the migration program who have such highly different standards and principles from those of the great majority of Australians is somewhat reprehensible. I remind the Senate that acquired immune deficiency syndrome is almost entirely transmitted in the Western world by promiscuous homosexuals. In the United States of America only 5 per cent of the 10,000 cases of AIDS already reported have occurred among people who are not members of the high risk group, that is, homosexuals. We have enough problems at the moment internally without adding such a group of people to our migration program.

The whole blood transfusion program is now at risk in the public mind. A very high proportion of people nowadays are advising their doctors not to give them blood transfusions if they go to hospital. I think it is a tragedy, for example, that a 66-year old San Franciscan nun contracted this disease through a blood transfusion. Already in Australia two babies have died from AIDS as a result of blood transfusions. The recommendations of the Human Rights Commission certainly will not help this situation.

In conclusion, I say that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hurford, has been quoted in the Australian as saying that the migration policy, in regard to homosexuals, is unlikely to be changed. I hope that he will not be influenced by this section of the Human Rights Commission's report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It had not occurred to me to contemplate entering this debate on the report of the Human Rights Commission on Human Rights relating to the Migration Act 1958. However, I would not want the Senate to assume that my friend and colleague Senator Watson speaks, in all that he says, for every senator on this side of the chamber. While I agree with aspects of the way in which the Human Rights Commission has dealt with the question of discrimination against the homosexual partners of persons otherwise eligible to enter Australia, I regard myself as being, in Senator Watson's words, 'a decent living Australian'. Nevertheless, I do not find myself grossly offended, insulted or, indeed, threatened by the Commission's recommendation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is most unfortunate that in a matter such as this, comments about the spread of acquired immune deficiency syndrome are dragged into the debate in a way which simply perpetuates the homophobic and unfortunate attitude towards this crisis, which is fundamentally a public health crisis, which is not helpful to the victims and sufferers. Of the 17 or so people who have died in Australia of the disease AIDS, one of them was closely and personally known to me. He was a person whose death touched me as a lost friend. I make no secret of that. It is not a matter I find embarrassing or something to be ashamed of.

Senator Watson mentioned that AIDS is largely transmitted by promiscuous homosexuals. That may or may not be a totally accurate statement. Let us take it for the moment that that may be a totally accurate statement. The fact is that the Human Rights Commission, in dealing with this matter, says that it wants to recognise the relationship of homosexuals who are in a permanent relationship. A 'permanent relationship' is a relationship which excludes, I think, the term 'promiscuous' in the way in which Senator Watson used it. I believe that the de facto relationship is difficult to establish in terms of bona fides, whether it be between homosexual or heterosexual couples. The question has been raised of whether the institution of marriage-an institution in which I have the deepest belief-is threatened or not threatened by de facto relationships. That threat would be equally true regardless of the sexual nature of the partners in the de facto relationship, or in the sanctified relationship of marriage.

I do not want to get involved in the debate other than to go on the record as saying that it is my view that, where bona fide relationships exist, if they are based upon the principles of love, mutual respect and commitment, I make no moral judgment on the basis that the relationship is between persons of the same or of the opposite sex. I do not find anything repellant about the Human Rights Commission's recommendation. I feel insulted by Senator Watson's remark that the recommendation would be repellant to 'decent living Australians'. If anyone else believes that because I do not find these relationships offensive I do not qualify as a decent living Australian, I find that regrettable. I hope that when matters of this nature are considered they might be considered with a little less emotion, a little more sensitivity and a little recognition that differences, particularly those differences grounded in real feelings of mutual love and respect, are matters to be respected and not matters to be made part of an unfortunate, divisive, politically unhelpful debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on this matter. My comments also arise from the remarks made by Senator Watson. I have no difficulty in speaking about the recommendation of the report of the Human Rights Commission on Human Rights and the Migration Act 1958 which, as Senator Puplick says, refers to permanent and long standing relationships between homosexuals. I have no hesitation and no problem in echoing the words of Senator Puplick. I believe he articulated my view and, I am sure, the views of many other people in this place on that matter most adequately. I equally believe that Senator Watson is, in his own words, 'a decent, clean living Australian'. Therefore, I ask him to consider whether he is assisting the cause, assisting the Commonwealth Government of Australia and all the State governments in their efforts to deal with what is a very serious public health problem, by spending most of his speaking time opposing the first recommendation of the Human Rights Commission report by talking about AIDS-the acquired immune deficiency syndrome-in the way in which he did.

SPEECH.PARA: I emphasise that the AIDS problem in this and in other countries is a public health problem. It is recognised as such by all governments of this country which are co-operating in an effort to handle that public health problem. Dr Blewett, the Minister for Health, I imagine by now has made a long and detailed statement to the House of Representatives that he was due to make this afternoon on what the State and Federal governments are doing in this matter. But what is also important in coping with this public health problem is that we have the co-operation of not only the health authorities but also the communities at risk, and one of the communities at risk in this country is the homosexual community. By and large the authorities have had the co-operation of that community through education and discussion, and will continue to do so. It may be, as Senator Watson says, that the most common source of the spread of the disease in this country-before we knew what the disease was, by the way-was through what he chooses to describe as 'promiscuous homosexuals'. That does not apply everywhere and need not apply here. In New York, for instance, the most common cause of the spread of the disease is understood to be through people who are intravenous drug users.

I think the worst thing about his opposing the recommendation of the Human Rights Commission, which was about allowing people in long-standing and permanent relationships to be joined in this country-I do not object to his having those views-is that he believes he will be assisting the public health effort against the spread of AIDS in Australia. I think he is gravely mistaken. If we treat this as anything but a public health problem; if we treat it, as I said the other day, as some would, as a visitation from on high; if we treat it as something which has been sent to punish our society, and in doing so single out groups in the way in which I believe John Watson perhaps unwittingly did today, we are not going to assist a sensible approach to the public health problem that we have. We are not going to assist sensible debate in this country but we will divide this society in a way that I do not think anyone in this Parliament should. I therefore ask him to consider the words that he said, no matter how unfortunately inadvertent they may have been. I do not think he will assist the cause in the future if he continues in this way.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SPECIAL ASSISTANCE FOR THE NORTHERN TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In speaking to the Commonwealth Grants Commission fifth report 1985 on special assistance for the Northern Territory I note that in July 1978, by virtue of the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act, a financial arrangement was made between the Federal Government and the Northern Territory. Under clause 2 of the memorandum of understanding the Northern Territory Government became eligible to apply for a grant of special assistance on the recommendation of the Commonwealth Grants Commission on a basis similar to that of the claimant State. The introduction in the report states in part:
In conformity with this agreement, the Commonwealth Grants Commission Amendment Act 1978 was enacted to enable the Commission to inquire into and report to the Minister upon such applications.

The Commonwealth Grants Commission has been a very responsible statutory body over very many years and has been responsible for recommending funding to claimant States from the Federal Government. I believe that the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission fifth report on special assistance for the Northern Territory have put the lie to the accusations of financial extravagance and overspending which have been recently made against the Northern Territory Government. Quite clearly, the Grants Commission has looked at the situation and has made a report to the Government and the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) and yet it is the Minister who makes these attacks on the Northern Territory, despite the Commission's recommendations.

The report, it is true, comes to the conclusion that for the financial year 1982-83 the Northern Territory received Commonwealth assistance of some $355,498,000, whereas its assessed needs were $342,886,000. In effect, the Commission says that the Territory received some $12,600,000 in excess of the amount it needed to provide services to the people of the Territory on a similar basis to the services which are provided to residents of the States. The report of the Commission states that the Commission has attempted to assess the Territory's financial need by determining the level of expenditure the Territory would incur if it pursued the same expenditure policies as do the standard States-New South Wales and Victoria.

It is to be noted that the Grants Commission has not applied the factor assessment method because it has difficulty in obtaining data and in evaluating that data. That not having been done, one wonders what the situation would be under the financial arrangements for the Northern Territory, under the memorandum of understanding regarding special circumstances, if, for instance, the remoteness of the area, the small population and the high percentage of Aboriginal people living amongst the Territory population were taken into account as extra funds are required for their welfare. Even taking the approach it has, the Commission has come up with the figure of only $12m as the amount received by the Territory in 1982-83 in excess of its requirements for the provision of services to its residents.

I must say that I believe this is a paltry sum when one considers the money which the Commonwealth grabbed back from the Territory last week when, despite the recommendations of the Commonwealth Grants Commission, the Treasurer, Mr Keating, announced the Government's economic package. He took $37m in one swipe from the Northern Territory Electricity Commission, which will bring tremendous pressure to bear on the people of the Northern Territory. That means that the rates will go up considerably. He took $36m in another swipe from funds destined for the redevelopment of Darwin Airport. In all, he took a total of $73m, and that is only the beginning because there have been cuts in defence in the Darwin area, cuts in education, in the petrol freight subsidy-which will bring enormous hardship to the people of the Territory-to the community employment program, communications and a host of other areas, which will all have a detrimental effect on the Northern Territory.

We are told by the Federal Government that these cuts are to be made because we have been extravagant in the Territory and because we have received excessive Commonwealth funding. But the size of the funding cuts to the Territory, in view of the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission, are totally out of proportion to any provision of excess Commonwealth funds. The fact is that funding cuts to the Territory have nothing to do with excessive Commonwealth funding or fiscal extravagance but everything to do with the fact that the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, are not interested in the people of the Territory who, on 1 December last year, failed to return one of their colleagues to the House of Representatives. If anyone doubts what the funding cuts are all about, he has only to look at the report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission, which makes it perfectly clear that the Territory is not guilty of the gross extravagance with which it has been charged and the excesses to which Senator Walsh so often and monotonously refers.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: DAIRY PRODUCE MARKET SUPPORT LEVY BILL 1985DAIRY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985DAIRY PRODUCE MARKET SUPPORT BILL 1985DAIRY INDUSTRY STABILIZATION LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch we were considering the Dairy Produce Market Support Levy Bill 1985 and associated Bills. (Quorum formed) I was referring to the fact that stocks of dairy products were at record levels, the European Economic Community and the United States between them having stocks in the range of two million tonnes. The magnitude of those stocks can be demonstrated by the fact that Australia, in 1983-84, exported a total of 92,000 tonnes. That provides a contrast in the degree of contribution we make to the pressures and fluctuations in price of these commodities as compared with that of the rest of the world. World prices for dairy products are therefore extremely depressed and the competition is so fierce that sales have been reported, as I said earlier, considerably below the minimum prices under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Nor is there any prospect of improvement in this situation. According to the Australian Bureau of Agricultural Economics, there will be no significant recovery in prices until at least 1986-87 with perhaps small declines in production in Europe and America being offset by increased production in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

SPEECH.PARA: Dairy farmers' incomes are currently protected to an extent by the existing market arrangements which subsidise export returns. The aim of the legislation before us is to reduce the level of that assistance which is given to the industry with the aim of cutting milk production. The industry certainly agrees that milk production needs to be reduced, but the effects of this Government's scheme are likely to be so drastic as to wreak absolute havoc on the dairy industry, particularly at a time when it is least able to accommodate it. This point was made very succinctly in an editorial in the Weekend Australian of 31 March 1985. It states:

What Mr Kerin seems to have overlooked is that Australian dairy farmers are very efficient producers and that most other nations with dairy industries give those industries enormous government support. The Australian Government should not sacrifice the future of Australian dairy farmers for the profits of their counterparts in Europe, the US or New Zealand.

That is exactly what will happen. Australia will vacate the world market and the gap will be filled by the United States, the EEC and New Zealand. As the Industries Assistance Commission pointed out in its report on the dairy industry in November 1983, there has been very substantial rationalisation of the dairy industry since the early 1970s, resulting in fewer and larger dairy holdings. I illustrate that point. Between 1971 and 1982, the number of dairy holdings with less than 60 cattle fell by 75 per cent while the number of holdings with a herd of over 200 cattle increased by only 28 per cent. Since 1982, however, milk production has been slowly increasing. From 5,200 million litres in 1980-81, milk production is expected to reach over 6,000 million litres by the end of 1984-85. This is perhaps reflected in the number of herds and productivity gains. The domestic market for milk is unlikely to increase substantially; therefore, surplus milk products must be sold on the export market, which, as I have already indicated, is extremely depressed and is likely to remain so in the near future.

The Bureau of Agricultural Economics, in an economic evaluation of the dairy industry based on its submission to the IAC inquiry, made the point that investment, production and consumption decisions in the long term for the dairy industry must be made on the economic reality of long term world dairy prices. The dairy industry must be able to meet fair competition, with a level of production sufficient to provide exports for remunerative markets. That means that there must be an excess of production beyond that available for domestic consumption. Ultimately, this means a lower level of assistance to the industry, but the transfer must be done with great care. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics submission said:

The costs associated with a rapid dismantling of the present transfer arrangements could be very high . . . adjustment would affect most adversely the small group of farmers unable to reduce their costs . . . the rapid removal of present transfers might result in unnecessary adjustment costs and hardship if the industry contracted beyond its long-term stable level of production in response to export parity prices . . . removal of the present assistance would increase the Australian industry's vulnerability to the relatively unstable world market.

The present dairy marketing arrangements support domestic prices for manufactured products to an average figure approximately 70 per cent above that of export prices. The aim of the new marketing plan is to reduce this support to 30 per cent above export prices. This aim, by and large, is supported by the industry. This legislation is to be achieved by a levy on all milk production, sufficient to provide a level of support of 30 per cent above the average export prices, over three years, working out at around 1.5c per litre. Other calculations, contrary to mine, show the figure at 1.4c, but it is somewhere between 1.4c and 1.5c per litre. To provide a buffer between the present arrangements and this much lower level of assistance, a levy has been imposed upon butter and cheese sufficient to maintain current domestic prices on dairy produce. However, after 1985-86 this support will be dramatically cut. According to a formula, if milk production and market milk prices remain the same, the levy on butter and cheese will be halved. If milk production increases, the levy will be reduced even further.

There is a very real and quite proper fear in the dairy industry that the imposition of the levy on all milk production might encourage farmers actually to increase production to maintain their incomes. In that case, by 1986-87, a very severe cut in prices would result in a sharp reduction in the levy on butter and cheese, resulting in a cut in farmers' returns of such magnitude as would cause excessive adjustment in the industry. That is one of the dangers, as already indicated, that was remarked upon by the BAE. It has been touched upon by almost every speaker on this side of the House. In order to avoid this situation the levy could be reduced in four equal steps to effect a more gradual reduction in assistance. Additionally, current levels of assistance should be maintained for two years rather than one. This would give world dairy prices some chance, modest as it might be, to improve, thereby reducing the likelihood that the industry will overadjust.

Compounding these problems is the decision of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) immediately to scrap the system of export pooling. As we know, under present dairy marketing arrangements an average export price is determined for each dairy product by the Australian Dairy Corporation for the coming financial year, taking into account expected movements in the world price. All exports then receive the average price. The export pool is supported by any surplus from the pooling process and from levies on domestic production. In the long term, it is agreed that export pooling should be phased out. In order to enable a greater responsiveness to export markets, however, simply to scrap the system in a few weeks time is to invite chaos into the industry. This type of unilateral, arbitrary decision, in my view, has never been cast or imposed upon any other industry. The Industries Assistance Commission proposed scrapping export pooling in its draft report on the dairy industry, but subsequently it accepted the argument that to do that would 'induce an unacceptable level of instability into producer returns and would place considerable adjustment pressure on the industry'. Consequently the IAC recommended the retention of export pooling subject to review within three years.

This Government is arguing that to abolish export pooling would encourage manufacturers to develop new and more lucrative markets. While there may be some merit in that argument in the long run, it is obvious that this cannot be achieved by 1 July 1985, after which date it is proposed by Mr Kerin, Senator Walsh and the Labor Government that export pooling be scrapped. In addition, in the present situation in which produce is being sold at below GATT minimum prices, it is very likely that Australian producers will be forced to compete with each other in their most lucrative markets to the point where export returns could be beaten down even further than today's levels or those predicted.

The speed with which this Government is attempting to force adjustment upon the dairy industry is totally unrealistic. The nature of dairy farming is such that it takes years rather than weeks to alter production levels. The consequences of ignoring that fact will be very severe indeed. I cannot believe that this Government does not understand that an industry of this nature cannot adjust overnight in the way that is intended in this legislation. Mr Vawser, the Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation, in his address to the BAE National Outlook Conference at the beginning of this year spoke on the decision on marketing arrangements for the industry. He said:
Without foresight and understanding, the industry could be reduced to a rump, to the ultimate detriment of the economy and the Australian community.

Unfortunately, this seems to be where the industry is heading with the Kerin plan. The Australian Dairy Farmers Federation has expressed fears that Labor's plan will force so severe a cut in production that Australia could actually be short of milk in three years time. Additionally, the Federation predicts the loss of up to 25,000 jobs. The repercussions on rural communities would be immense. One need not be very bright or enlightened to understand that the vast majority of those jobs will be lost in rural areas which are already subject to very high levels of unemployment, and where it is very difficult to find alternative work and to sell homes and move to another location.

I find it very interesting to compare the attitude taken by this Labor Government to protection afforded the dairy industry with its attitude to the levels of assistance which shelter many of our manufacturing industries-industries which have high levels of employment and intensive labour, and where there are strong unions affiliated with the Australian Council of Trade Unions which have muscle with this Government. Total Commonwealth outlays on the dairy industry in 1984-85 are estimated to reach only $11m. I ask honourable senators to compare that figure with the $78.1m allocated to the textile industry or the $52m paid in bounties to the incompetent, inefficient, subsidised steel industry in the same year.

The BAE estimates the economic cost of assistance to the dairy industry at between $25m and $40m a year, depending on whether one takes export or import parity prices. The cost of protection to consumers is minimal. It is somewhere between $15 and $25 a year per person, again depending on whether or not one uses export or import parity prices in one's calculations. Even $40m pales into insignificance when compared with the $1,500m a year costs that the manufacturing sector's tariffs impose upon the rural sector as a whole. That works out at a cost of $9,000 per farm in subsidies to the manufacturing sector that are cast upon the rural sector.

The Balderstone report entitled 'Agricultural Policy: Issues and Options for the 1980s' noted the deleterious effects of protection on agriculture and suggested that the levels of protection should be reduced 'starting with the most highly protected industries'. Nobody can claim in honesty, in truth and with confidence that the most highly protected industry is the rural sector; it is one of the very lowest. The National Farmers Federation commented on this point in its submission on farm costs. With the exception of the financial sector the Federation submitted:
The delay in action to reduce protection is becoming so serious as to constitute a serious threat to the general viability of the Australian economy.

The response of this Labor Government, far from starting with the most highly protected industries, is to hack away at the least protected sector of the Australian economy-the rural sector. It is particularly unfortunate, to say the least, that the Government should opt for this course of action when the chance of pursuing a more sensible and gradual policy of adjustment is so apparent. Such a policy is available and is the subject of our amendment. This policy could be rationally accepted and put in place. It would have the good will and support of the rural sector, the public and the Opposition. For some reason which escapes my attention and the logic of colleagues on my side of the House, that decision will not be made. The decision that has been made is arbitrarily to chop support from the industry.

My concluding point concerns the proposed termination of allowances to manufacturers for certain costs, primarily storage and interest payments. This again illustrates the unnecessary harshness of Labor's dairy plan and its willingness to leave the Australian industry extremely vulnerable on the international market. The Australian Dairy Farmers Federation points out that under this legislation:

Australia will be the only country signatory to the GATT international minimum pricing agreement for dairy products which does not have a centralised system for meeting storage costs of products when markets cannot be found above minimum prices.

What I find intriguing about this question of protection, in regard to both the dry dries on our side and the wet wets on the other side, is that there never seems to be any rational balance. The logical conclusion seems to be that Australia ought to abolish all its protection-all its tariffs and all its bounties-and expose itself to the vulnerability of competition from the rest of the world, which continues to have tariffs and bounties. Then we have the other situation in which the manufacturing sector particularly has become flush and has grown fat, weary, lazy, incompetent and inefficient as a result of the level of taxpayers' funds that has been used in the past to prop it up.

In my view the rational course of action is for us to reduce our levels of protection, our levels of assistance, when they are compatible with the levels of assistance provided by other countries. It is absurd for us to be, with the exception of New Zealand, the only country that does not have some form of subsidy of the nature that in particular the United States and the European Community have. It is absurd for anybody to expect us to be able to compete on the world market with the European Community and the United States, given the enormous stocks and levels of protection they have. This is a particularly serious matter at present when world dairy prices are so low that frequently Australian exporters are unable to sell products above the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade minimum price. The European Community is dumping in the countries that are our traditional consumers and in our future markets, in the Third World countries. As a result of this legislation we just will not be competitive.

As I said at the outset, the industry is quite happy to adjust. It is quite happy to remove the wrinkles, to rationalise and to take less subsidy than it is presently receiving providing it is given time to adjust in a sensible and proper way. What a stark change that is from the position the Victorian Government took immediately before the last election. As an earlier speaker in this debate said, the last election in Victoria was probably won on the basis of the Victorian Government's deceit and dishonesty. It gave the Victorian industry to believe that it supported the proposition now put by the Federal Opposition. The Victorian Government said that it agreed with the general proposal of all the States for the orderly adjustment of the marketing arrangements for manufactured milk. What did the Commonwealth Government say at the time? It was deafening in its silence. It gave tacit support, tacit approval and tacit agreement to Mr Cain. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of dairy industry Bills proposed by the Government is, as far as the Opposition is concerned, inadequate and require amendment. Amendments will be moved later in the Committee stage. I suggest first that the industry itself did recognise the problems of overproduction. The various sectors of the industry were very careful to consult amongst themselves and proposals were put before the various State Ministers and the Federal Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) some time last year. These proposals were accepted unanimously by the Ministers concerned, so it is with some concern that we find that the Bills before us today ignore the disruption that would occur to the industry if the Bills were allowed to pass without amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps the most surprising, and certainly the most deplorable, feature of the proposed new dairy marketing arrangements is the deceit practised by the Minister for Primary Industry as shown by the contrast between the tenor of the discussions he held with the industry last year and the draconian sweep of the legislation evident in these four Bills. Perhaps we could add the contrast between the pretended intentions of the legislation as expressed in the Minister's second reading speeches and the actual impact on the dairy industry. Introducing the Dairy Produce Market Support Levy Bill-the first of the four Bills in this package-the Minister stated:
. . . when world prices began to decline present marketing arrangements continued to encourage production increases.

The Minister then asked us to 'contemplate the insanity of a marketing arrangement which rewards individual manufacturers for continuing to produce for export, when these exported products in some cases return less than half the cost of production of the milk used in their manufacture'. If we overlook the fact-and we can do that-that the milk production increases which the Minister deplores were produced at marginal cost and that the cost of converting the milk into dairy products was also marginal, the true cost may well have been only a fraction of the average cost and the productive use of otherwise idle resources may have been a sensible economic choice.

Let us look instead at the intentions of the Bills now before us to see whether they remedy the ills of which the Minister complains. Let us overlook also the fact that the domestic prices for Australian dairy products are among the cheapest in the world. That fact has been demonstrated repeatedly during the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —And top quality.

—As Senator Crichton-Browne said, our dairy products are top quality. We observe from the second reading speeches that although the Minister conceded that world market prices are corrupt, so that some measure of assistance in the form of higher domestic prices is reasonable, Australian consumers now support the dairy industry by paying higher prices for their dairy products than would be the case in the absence of the current market arrangements. We also observe from the same sources that the proposed abolition of export pooling is to ensure competition between manufacturers for export markets. Both of these measures, separately and together, will eventually result in lower returns to dairy farmers. I think Senator Crichton-Browne and others have alluded to that.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, the aim of the legislation to reduce returns to a point where a large number of dairy farmers-some 25 per cent-are forced out of the industry, is demonstrated by the formula in clause 7 (3) of the Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy Amendment Bill. That clause permits current levels of farm prices to be maintained, and then for only two years, only if national milk production falls by some 24 per cent. It is therefore difficult to see why, if a fall in prices under the current arrangements would induce increased milk production, there should be any different reaction to the price reduction which is intended by the proposed legislation. I believe quite firmly, and I understand that this belief is held generally by the dairy industry, that whilst price reductions will follow the introduction of the proposed legislation, if it gets that far-and I include here the steep initial reduction that would occur in the opening prices on 1 July, which is the proposed commencement date for this new legislation, as well as the expected and intended downward price movement during at least the early years of the new scheme-there will be an immediate increase in milk production as every dairy farmer attempts to at least maintain his gross income, at best to offset steadily increasing production costs.

This steep increase in milk production will lead to even larger volumes of products that cannot be sold at any price because of international agreements, followed immediately by a massive reduction in farm income and an even faster rate of exit from the dairy industry. This would be caused by foreclosures and other financial pressures, followed by increasing production as prices recover-an overshoot and a continuous but diminishing typical cobweb behaviour until equilibrium is reached, if it is reached, about the time the legislation is to terminate. This instability and its economic, social and personal costs, could be avoided if the Minister were to honour what amounts to an undertaking that he gave to the Australian Dairy Industry Conference in August last year. On that occasion, the Minister stated, I believe unequivocally:

Equalisation arrangements of the type now in place and as proposed give the wrong marginal price signals to producers . . . I believe that, for the dairy industry, the price mechanism is a fairly blunt weapon for tailoring production to remunerative demand.
I remind the Senate that the sole regulatory mechanism in the Bills before the chamber is that of price. The Minister, on that occasion last year, continued:
For those reasons I am still open to be convinced that the advantages of an entitlements scheme may outweigh the disadvantages.

Then the Minister laid down the conditions on which he was prepared to put forward an entitlements scheme. Those conditions were that the scheme should be simple; it would need to have broad industry support; it should be structured so as not to freeze the structure of the industry; it should not give rise to high values for entitlements, and it should not institutionalise a level of production that is above remunerative market opportunities. Regrettably, although the industry supports the principle of production restraint through an entitlements scheme and had proposed an amendment to those Bills which it believes would facilitate the introduction of such a scheme, the industry has not addressed itself to meeting the specific conditions which the Minister set down for entitlements to be acceptable to him and, one must presume, to the Government.

First, let us deal with the simplicity of the scheme. Reference has been made to the necessity for such a scheme to be acceptable to all State governments because complementary State legislation will be required. The 1976 report of the Industries Assistance Commission recommended an entitlements scheme as the second stage in the progressive deregulation of its then proposed-and now current-stabilisation scheme. It proposed that the scheme be centrally administered by the Australian Dairy Corporation; a proposal that surely represents the absolute in terms of simplicity, equity and impartiality. As to broad industry support, the support then given to an entitlements scheme by the Australian Dairy Industry Conference-the industry's official mouthpiece-was reinforced seven months later by all State Ministers of agriculture at a meeting on 28 February, which the Minister reported in his media release on 1 March as demonstrating the degree of support which would enable him to put the proposal to the Government.

The third condition of the avoidance of structural rigidity was met, shortly after the Minister's address, by the acceptance by the industry of free negotiability of entitlements; a condition that had always been insisted on by the Minister and had been recommended in the 1976 IAC report. The condition concerning the avoidance of high capitalisation values for entitlements is perhaps harder to meet, but several suggestions have been put to me by the industry, all of which appear to have merit and could well be combined. I am sure that a fixed life, perhaps as short as two years or as long as the proposed four years, prior to a review of the scheme, would provide sufficient uncertainty to keep entitlement values to a workable minimum.

Meeting the final condition-an entitlements scheme that is confined to remunerative markets-will depend on an agreed identity of remunerative markets which, in the generally unstable world dairy market structure, vary almost from day to day. But agreement here should present no difficulty and surely is outside the contents of a Bill. The question is simply whether the 5.6 billion litres proposed by the industry includes some unremunerative markets or whether entitlements should include domestic and so-called preferred export markets favoured by the IAC; whether the Minister's original maximum of 5 billion litres is better or whether the goal should be to effect a rapid reduction from some higher figure down to the 4.6 billion litres as proposed in the Minister's plan put to the Australian Agricultural Council on 11 February.

However, the undoubted merits of an entitlement scheme as a means of ensuring a stable, viable and efficient dairy industry are not sufficient to enable such a scheme to stand alone as the only modifying factor in the proposed new legislation. For example, the 1976 IAC report recommended that the transition from stage 1 to stage 2 of its three-part proposal, which transition regrettably failed, should include a fully negotiable entitlement scheme and the retention of the export pooling component of the equalisation pools in stage 1-a recommendation that was reiterated by the IAC in its 1983 report.

The amendment which is proposed to clause 19 of the Dairy Produce Market Support Bill was similarly supported by the IAC in section 5.2 of its 1976 report for the same reasons as have been put forward; namely, that the primary purpose of the proposed legislation is to support the dairy farming sector of the industry so that support payments should be related to that portion of manufactured dairy products that is supplied by the dairy farmer-the milk and milk constituents content, not the labour, packaging and other costs added during the manufacturing process.

Finally, I turn to the amendment that will be suggested to clause 7 of the Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy Amendment Bill. I have already referred to the fair deal that I believe Australian consumers receive when they buy Australian dairy products, the prices for which are among the cheapest in the world, in contrast to the Minister's view that our consumers pay too much. The purpose of the amendment is no more than to extend the transition period during which domestic pricing moves from arbitrary levels of support to a predetermined price relative to export prices. Even in the market signal environment created by an entitlement scheme, if we have regard to the continuing increases in dairy farm and factory production costs and the fact that domestic prices for dairy products have not increased for over two years, the rate of production proposed in the Bill must be regarded as unacceptably rapid. I have consulted closely with the South Australian dairy industry. I am grateful for the advice that has been given to me by Mr David Higbed. I congratulate the Minister on the effectiveness of his consultation with the industry and I sincerely trust that the Senate will pass the amendments at the appropriate time so that this important industry will not suffer the disruption that these Bills would create.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Apart from the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), I think I am the last of the speakers on the Dairy Produce Market Support Levy Bill and related Bills. The facts about the industry, its problems, its difficulties and the Government's solutions to them have been put to the Senate at length. It is very interesting that, notwithstanding the fact that there were about 15 speakers, only one Government senator was prepared to speak on these Bills and the effect that they will have on this very important industry. I must say that I did enjoy Senator Cooney's speech. I hear some laughter from the Government side, but I mean that. I thought that his effort to put the Government's case was excellent.
—He made a better effort than a lot of them.
—As Senator Collard said, he made a better effort than the rest of them because, of course, the rest of them did not even try. But Senator Cooney demonstrated that he can handle a brief.
—He has been doing that for a number of years.
—Yes. I suppose that is what lawyers are trained to do. But in any event he did it fairly well and what he was saying came across-
—Would you employ him; this is it?

—Yes, certainly I would have briefed him in my time. What he said came across as very reasonable. Unfortunately, though, his instructions were demonstrably wrong in five areas, as outlined in the speech by Senator Archer. I will not bother to repeat those areas; they are set out very clearly in Senator Archer's speech.

SPEECH.PARA: One point about Senator Cooney's speech that I do wish to take up is that he asked for evidence that more than a small minority of farmers will be put at risk by the legislation. He seemed to imply that if this could be demonstrated the Government might change its mind about this legislation. Of course, we know that that will not happen because Senator Walsh has already told us that the Government will not change its mind and will reject our amendments. The fact that Senator Cooney is asking such a question is, in my view, clear evidence that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has been dissembling when addressing the ALP Caucus to explain the legislation.

If one looks at the Minister's second reading speeches, the proposition does not come clearly through. In fact I found it necessary to examine all the second reading speeches and then go back to look at his public statements as shown in his Press releases in order ultimately to reduce this legislation to three simple propositions. This is the evidence which I present to Senator Cooney: The plan is designed to cut back production of milk to what the Minister describes as what can be sold profitably. The Minister has made it clear that that is what the plan is all about. That amount, the Minister has indicated in other speeches, he estimates at about 4.6 billion litres per annum. Production is estimated at 6 billion litres for this year. The conclusion is that it is necessary to cut back by 1.4 billion litres. That is the evidence for which Senator Cooney was asking and it was clearly demonstrated by the fact that we have this legislation before the Senate at the moment. If that were not the purpose of the legislation we would not be debating these Bills. This ALP proposal requires these dairy farmers to cut back by this 1.4 billion litres per annum, in effect forthwith-commencing in six weeks time.

I refer to a speech by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator John Button, on 17 October 1984 in an address to the Australian Business Congress. Again it was a speech which I admired, an excellent speech. Of course, at that stage Senator Button was wearing that hat he wears when he addresses businessmen and not the hat he wears when he addresses unionists. There is sometimes a difference. In the course of this speech Senator Button said:

If industry policy was solely a matter of lowering protection levels . . . and watching resources shift into more efficient sectors, restructuring would be simple, but we should not delude ourselves into believing that any government in Australia, or elsewhere in the world, has unequivocally accepted wholesale tariff reduction as a principal arm of economic policy.

Senator Button was talking about industries which are not primary industries. He was pointing out that if one were trying to shift resources and it was just simply a matter of lowering protection levels and watching industry become efficient, it would be very easy. He went on to say:
The main qualification to this approach lies in the speed in which tariff reduction can be carried out.
This Government--
Senator Button's Government--
has announced its intention to proceed to reduce levels of protection, but in areas such as motor vehicle policy it has done so on a gradual basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —The right way.
—As Senator Archer says, the right way. It has done it on a gradual basis. That is what our amendments are all about.
—That is all anybody wants.

—As Senator Archer says, it is all anybody wants. I make no criticism of Senator Button for that approach. I admire him for his approach to the industry and I hope that he can successfully restructure Australian manufacturing and secondary industries in the way that he is going about it. When one looks at what Mr Kerin is proposing in regard to the dairy industry, one wonders why he does not go and get a lesson from Senator Button. If these cows were mechanical cows, the pressure of the Australian Council of Trade Unions on this Government would have resulted in a plan for restructuring the industry very different from the plan which Mr Kerin-
—They would be on clover.

—I acknowledge Senator Collard's pun. This Government's plan to restructure the dairy industry is, in effect, to take out of the industry some 2,000 to 3,000 of the 19,000 current Australian dairy farmers. As has been pointed out in the Senate, this industry has been involved in extensive restructuring for over a decade. In the last few years, since about 1977, it has restructured massively. Yet this proposal is to wipe out another 2,000 to 3,000 Australian dairy farmers. Which dairy farmers will be wiped out? Not the market milk suppliers. Those who are currently receiving about 30c per litre and struggling to survive on 50-cow dairy farms are not the ones who will be wiped out. Those people have my sympathy. I know the difficulties and the harshness of their work.

SPEECH.PARA: When I first went to Warrnambool in the mid-1950s I knew people who were surviving on 50-cow dairies. They were probably milking in dairies erected by their grandfathers and, in some cases, great grandfathers, in mud and slush up to their knees in winter and generally in very poor conditions. But they managed to survive by milking 50 cows twice a day seven days a week. These dairy farmers do not exist any longer in the efficient areas of Victoria. There are young, enthusiastic dairy farmers milking 110 to 120 cows a day and not in mud and slush up to their elbows but, in fact, in modern circular dairies with silos to provide feed and with all the latest equipment. They are doing very well. Certainly those who are supplying market milk in Brisbane and Sydney, and Adelaide for that matter, have my sympathy. On the other hand, they will continue to be protected by State government schemes.

The dairy farmers who are required to cut back under this legislation are those who supply manufacturing milk. They are currently surviving on 13c or 14c a litre and milking double the number of cows with probably just the minimum of help from their family. Mostly Victorians and some Tasmanians will be wiped out because 87 per cent of their production goes into manufacturing milk, which is the area to be cut back. Most of these people are young dairy farmers who are in debt. They are not in debt because there has been anything wrong with their methods; they are in debt because they have borrowed funds to become efficient to cope with the cutbacks which occurred in the late 1970s. Many of them have leased or purchased larger farms; they have bought or bred larger herds; they have built new efficient dairies and new silos and made sure that the cows are well cared for with concrete paths. Generally the whole industry is so much more efficient than it was 25 years or so ago. These people are being given some five to six weeks under this legislation.

The amendments which the Opposition is proposing are designed to extend that transition period to two years to give these farmers some time to change their product and to give their co-operatives time to reorganise their international marketing arrangements. I certainly hope that those co-operatives take the opportunity that is given to them because that is an essential reorganisation in the industry. Another matter which bothers me is that most of these dairy farmers will go out of the dairy industry and into the beef industry. That will ultimately be to the detriment of that industry. But that is another problem which no doubt we will be confronted with at some stage in the future.

Senator Walsh in demonstrating his and this Government's utter and complete contempt for both the Parliament and the legislative process has told us that we on the Opposition benches must accept the Government's ultimatum or else. If the Australian Labor Party had its way, Australia would have a one-party system of government and democracy and the parliamentary system would be right out of the window. Senator Walsh interjected on a previous speaker. If my memory serves me correctly, it was Senator Watson. He asked what our amendments will cost. Firstly, I say to Senator Walsh that our amendments provide no additional cost to the taxpayer. Indeed, it could be argued that by extending the adjustment period over two years the burden to the taxpayer will be reduced. Secondly, I refer to the cost to the consumer. Export pooling has, at the most, a minor indirect effect on the domestic price and may be disregarded altogether. In theory the Government's formula could provide higher domestic prices in a particular year. The basis for determining the export market payments, which is the subject of our third amendment, has no relationship to or effect on domestic prices. I ask Senator Walsh to apply his mind properly to the costs of these amendments rather than to apply his rhetoric.
Let me finish with some quotes from the editorial of the Australian of 30 March this year. It says:
Mr Kerin says we have too many dairy farmers producing too much milk, butter and other manufactured dairy products. He wants to make the industry competitive with overseas dairy industries.

What Mr Kerin seems to have overlooked is that Australian dairy farmers are very efficient producers and that most other nations with dairy industries give those industries enormous government support. European dairy farmers' home markets are protected by subsidies and tariffs and the European Community has built up surpluses.

While Australia may well have too many dairy farmers who produce too much, can we in these days of very high unemployment afford to implement a scheme which it has been estimated will see up to 9,000 efficient dairy farmers go out of business?
I did not suggest a figure of 9,000. The estimate that has been given to me is 2,000 to 3,000. The editorial goes on:
Even if we forget the farmers, imagine the impact on small rural communities if half Australia's dairy farmers were suddenly forced out of business.

Certainly, there is a need for urgent international talks on dairy industry rationalisation-but while other governments are protecting their dairy industries the Australian Government should not sacrifice the future of Australian dairy farmers for the profits of their counterparts in Europe, the US or New Zealand.

That puts it as well as anyone in the Senate has put it, and certainly better than I can. Why should we sacrifice dairy farmers in Australia for the benefit of their counterparts in Europe, the United States or New Zealand? All of Australia's product has been sold in the past few years and will continue to be sold. Perhaps it will not be sold profitably-which is the way Mr Kerin sees it-but it has been sold in the market-places and the probability is that it will continue to be sold. As our dairy farmers withdraw from the international market their places will simply be filled by dairy farmers in Europe, the United States or New Zealand and ultimately we will discover that 4.6 billion litres is too much milk and again we will have to cut back in some way. Why this Government should send dairy farmers to the wall in such a brief period when it is showing such a sensible approach to the manufacturing industry is quite beyond me.

On 27 February 1985 the Senate referred to this Committee the question of what penalties, if any, might, in the Committee's opinion, be appropriate with respect to the serious contempts of the Senate constituted by certain publications in the National Times the subject of the Committee's report, tabled on 17 October 1984 and adopted by the Senate on 24 October 1984.

In considering the matter, the Committee took into account certain written submissions made on behalf of John Fairfax and Sons Ltd, and Mr Brian Toohey and Ms Wendy Bacon of the National Times. The Committee also heard oral submissions on their behalf from Mr Neil McPhee, QC, at hearings on 3 April and 30 April 1985. Mr McPhee was accompanied by junior counsel and the instructing solicitors. Mr Max Suich, representing John Fairfax and Sons Ltd, and Mr Toohey and Ms Bacon also attended both hearings.

The Committee's general conclusion is that serious contempts of the type which occurred in 1984 warrant severe penalties. It has further concluded that such penalties should be imposed on any person who wilfully discloses private proceedings of a Committee without the authority of that Committee or the Senate, and on the organisation which is responsible for the publication of such proceedings. The severe penalty for the person who divulged the information would need to be determined at the time the offence was proved. So far as an organisation responsible for the publication is concerned, the Committee has concluded that a substantial fine is appropriate.

In the present case, the source of the information published by the National Times has not been discovered.
