SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill 1985 is a consequence of the mini-Budget brought down by the Government recently. I will give the Senate a brief history. When Senator Messner was Minister for Veterans' Affairs he instituted a scheme whereby all the repatriation legislation could be streamlined and consolidated into one piece of legislation. We believe that is a good idea. It makes it much simpler for everybody. The present Government has gone along with those plans. The ex-service organisations are well aware of that streamlining and consolidating procedure and they expected that it would result in a Veterans' Entitlement Bill to be brought into the House of Representatives this session to lie on the table during the winter recess to allow consultation with ex-service organisations prior to being debated in the Budget session. That was the expectation of the ex-service organisations. They were prepared to go along with that. They expected that any major alterations would be included in the Veterans' Entitlement Bill and that there would be adequate consultation with the Government and they could put forward their propositions, which the Government could either accept or reject. All the ex-service organisations had this expectation. While I have held the shadow portfolio of veterans' affairs wherever I have been I have found that expectation.

SPEECH.PARA: In the recent mini-Budget many changes were made to veterans' benefits. This legislation is the result of those changes. The ex-service organisations feel that they have been conned. Indeed, no less a person than Sir William Keys has said that in a Press release. Worse things have been said by other ex-service leaders in recent times, and I have been the recipient of some telexes. This indicates the feeling there is amongst the ex-service organisations at the way in which they have been treated. Earlier this year, with some sort of prophetic strategy, when addressing the Biennial Conference of the Australian Federation of Totally and Permanently Incapacitated Ex-Servicemen and Women, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, said:
If you want to see the Repatriation system preserved, it's time for you to make your voices heard.
So as not to take it out of context, I point out that he continued:

You need to lend your public support to a budgetary strategy which acknowledges the limitations, both political and economic, on the size of the deficit, while at the same time meeting our commitments to the veterans community.

I guess there we had the warning signals: 'If you want to see the repatriation system preserved, it's time for you to make your voices heard'. Of course, I took umbrage at that as did many other people in the ex-service organisations. People who have had to fight once for this country should not have to fight again for the entitlements that they believe are their just desserts. The Government is going down the track of cutting back on expenditure. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has indicated to us on many occasions that the Government will take a fine tooth comb through many government departments. I have no objection to that in general terms. Indeed, when we were in government we did the same thing. But it certainly appears to the veterans that they are being singled out for special action. They made a sacrifice once and are being asked to make a sacrifice again, and they do not like it.

The ex-service organisations accept the fact that, if there has to be a general belt tightening throughout the community, they are prepared to be part of it, within certain constraints. But in this instance it seems that the ex-service organisations are the ones being singled out. If there have to be sacrifices across the country, why are others not involved? Why do we not abolish the dole to the wives of strikers? Why do we not get rid of the Human Rights Commission? There are many areas in which we could save money without affecting the ex-diggers.

It is quite significant that at that time of the introduction of this legislation the Minister is overseas. I do not disagree with his going overseas for the Anzac ceremony that took place in Turkey; it was right that he should be there as the Minister representing the veterans of this country. He went over to that ceremony with ex-servicemen to represent us on Anzac Day. But when a piece of legislation with such far reaching ramifications as this one comes into the Parliament the Minister responsible for it should be here. Unfortunately, he is overseas.

Certain administrative changes are to be made. I believe some of them are good changes; they are necessary tidying up measures. I instance the changes relating to mental health. It is ridiculous that somebody should be kept in a mental institution if he does not need to be there. If such people can be moved out of that institution into a nursing home, where the atmosphere is obviously much better, or even into home care, that should be done. That is a plus in the Bill.

The direct crediting of pensions is also a plus. Obviously, this will save the Department a lot of money on the posting of cheques and in preventing the theft of cheques. The provisions relating to access to optometrists also makes sense. If we want to go to an optometrist, we go to one. But the situation with the veterans was that they had to go to a local medical officer, at a cost, to get a piece of paper to refer them to an optometrist. Those are administrative provisions which needed tidying up.

I refer now to section 47 of the Repatriation Act. When I first took over this shadow portfolio, as most honourable senators would be aware, veterans' affairs was not one of my favourite subjects, and certainly not one in which I was interested to any great extent. I was more interested in transport, communications, defence and so on. I had not heard of section 47 or Nancy Law or O'Brien. But it did not take me long to find out about them. As one moves around the ex-service organisations one finds that many of them have taken it upon themselves to look after those people who are not aware of the benefits available to them within the repatriation scheme. They study the legislation and, to their credit, they look after those who do not know their entitlements. They are experts on section 47 and the Nancy Law case. Indeed, it has not taken them long to be experts on the O'Brien case.

The most important and controversial amendment in this whole package is that relating to section 47. This section deals with the standard of proof required for a claim to be granted. It has been seen by the veterans as vital to the establishment of their entitlements. The present Act provides that the Commission shall grant a claim unless it is satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that there are insufficient grounds for granting the claim. The Bill seeks to change this in four respects. Firstly, in determining a claim with respect to death or incapacity the Commission must be reasonably satisfied that there is material before it that raises a reasonable hypothesis linking the death or incapacity to war service. Secondly, in the case of claimants with war service outside Australia the Commission shall grant a claim unless it is satisfied, beyond reasonable doubt, that there are insufficient grounds for granting the claim. This preserves the present situation except for the addition of the first example I have just given. Thirdly, in respect of any other claim, the Commission is prevented from granting the claim unless it is reasonably satisfied that there are sufficient grounds for granting a claim. This seems to suggest that the Commission has to be positively satisfied of the sufficiency of the evidence before granting a claim, and represents a major change from the present position. Fourthly, in making any further decisions under the Act or regulations, the Commission shall act to its reasonable satisfaction. This also changes the present position.

Section 47 and the lack of consultation are causing the greatest concern to the ex-service organisations. I thank the shadow Minister in the House of Representatives for doing a little bit of research. I will not go into detail, but on page 2840 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 21 May honourable senators will find the contribution made by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) to the debate on this legislation. He quoted the contribution made to the debate by Dr H. V. Evatt when section 47 was introduced. Dr Evatt was concerned that veterans should be well looked after. I think it is quite notable that after all the elder statesman of the Labor movement did for the veterans' organisations the Labor Party is now trying to change the onus of proof and the ramifications of section 47. We will not be opposing the Bill at the second reading stage but we will be moving to insert sunset clauses. I understand that the Government is prepared to accept those-

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you say you are a friend of the RSL if you let this Bill through? You will betray every ex-serviceman.

—The ex-service organisations want consultation regarding section 47. Sunset provisions in all the clauses pertaining to section 47 of the Act will allow the ex-service organisations and the Government time to consult. The Government must consult with them.
—So you want a whole lot of people to be affected between now and the Budget session? If you accepted our amendment you could have deferred it until the Budget session.

—The honourable senator will have her turn to debate this matter or Senator Macklin will have his turn on her behalf. We ought to keep faith with the ex-service organisations. I believe that they have been let down badly and have been conned. We are moving sunset clauses so that this Government can consult. It can then come back to this Parliament with whatever legislation has resulted from that consultation. We are not opposing the Bill.
—Does the RSL agree with that?
—I have advised the RSL and other ex-service organisations of the stand we are taking on this matter.
—Did they agree with it?
—At that stage they did not agree or disagree. I advised them of the stand we were taking.
—Senator Collard, will you address your remarks through the Chair.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, you even look better than Senator Chipp.
—What about me?

—It is near the end of a long session but even so Senator Haines is not looking too bad. We will not be opposing the Bill at the second reading stage, but we will be moving sunset clauses to allow adequate consultation. Quite obviously, if after that consultation changes are to be made to this legislation which affect any cases which are heard in the intervening period, any new legislation will take that into account.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Senate is debating the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill, which will amend the Repatriation Act in a number of ways. Many of the amendments are consequential on a series of substantial amendments throughout the Bill. The Australian Democrats' original position on this Bill was to vote against it. However, we knew that we would not have the Opposition's support; hence, we moved to a second position-to try to get a deferral of this legislation until the Budget session. The reason we took that stance was simply to keep the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) to the promise made in this chamber that no changes would be made to the Repatriation Act this session, that any proposed changes would be laid on the table and would be available to veterans' groups for consideration and consultation with their members and that the changes would be made in the Budget session.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is an open and flagrant violation of the promise made in this chamber by the Minister, whose whereabouts are unknown. The proposition put to this chamber by the Minister in answer to a question was not the only occasion upon which the Minister has made that type of assertion. I refer specifically to section 47 and a letter from the Minister dated 17 November 1984. It states:

Dear Sir Gordon, First you state that the retention of section 47 (2) is imperative and is fundamental. I agree with you in respect of determining whether a veteran's incapacity or death is related to his war service. I have stated on a number of occasions that there is no intention to change the onus or standard of proof which rests on the Repatriation Commission in deciding whether a disability is service related.
The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), who is in the chamber, in answer to a dorothy dixer the other day decided to attack me in regard to comments I made. She said-

TALK.START.PARA: —Misleading.
—The Minister should just listen. It will help her. She has no idea about this portfolio and what I have to say might be a useful education. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am advised that these comments are in many respects grossly inaccurate and misleading.
A Press release of 15 March last year from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs states:
The Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Arthur Gietzelt, has described comments made by Democrat Senator, Michael Macklin, on Repatriation legislation as misleading and misinformed.
This type of operation on the part of the Government seeking to denigrate me has been about what? The Press release continues:

Senator Gietzelt said it was malicious to say that the Act would be changed to require a Veteran to prove a claim rather than the Department to disprove a claim. The provisions of section 47 would remain as at present . . .

That is what the Minister said in attacks on me. That is precisely what this Bill does. To describe what I was doing as misleading is very interesting. It is the height of hypocrisy for the Minister for Education to say what she did when a Press release from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs has specifically said, in attacking me, that there would be no change to section 47. What do we have in this Bill? Clause 16 proposes a change to section 47. That is fairly typical of the type of operation which seeks to denigrate other people who are carrying out their duty to their constituents. The things that I was saying at that time have been proved to be true. They are in this Bill which the Government is trying to ram through the House tonight.
Letter after letter has been written and speech after speech has been made by the Minister in regard to section 47. He has gone on the record time and time again. I quote the Minister again:
The intention of the proposed legislation is to consolidate and simplify the provisions--

Oh, yes! Consolidate and simplify! The idea is to put into legislation the things that the Repatriation Commission could not get through the courts of this land. This is a sneaky, behind-the-scenes operation to do what the Commission could not do in open court.

TALK.START.PARA: —And with the collusion of the Liberals.

—Yes, with the collusion of the Opposition. If this Opposition had supported my amendment at the second reading stage at least the veterans of this country would have been given a chance to have a look at this matter. But the Opposition said 'Oh no, let's not do that. Let's make some other crawling operation and see whether we can curry a little bit of favour'. I wonder why the Opposition would not join with the Democrats in supporting the amendment in order to see whether we could hold the Minister to the promise he made in this chamber to go to the veterans.
—We are doing that.
—You are not doing it at all, not in the least. I return to the Minister's statement. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The intention of the proposed legislation is to consolidate and simplify the provisions relating to various repatriation benefits-
this is one of those soothing speeches made at conferences to try to calm down veterans; no doubt it was written by someone in the Department for that purpose-
available to veterans and their dependants. It is also intended to remove outmoded and discriminatory provisions in the present legislation. Let me also say firmly that it is not-
and the 'not' is underlined in this speech which was handed out to the Press-
the intention to change the onus of proof which rests on the Commonwealth in deciding if a disability is service-related.

It goes on and on and on. Here we have another one of those soothing documents put out by the Department to veterans telling them not to worry. In effect it is saying: 'Do not worry about what will happen. Section 47 as specifically mentioned is not being changed in this legislation'. That is the type of activity that we have seen.

What is the basis for this proposition that the Government has put forward in its economic statement? I draw an analogy with the Fraser dole bludger operation. This is the Hawke veteran bludger operation. The Government is trying to say: 'There are too many of these bludgers around'. It is trying to catch everyone through the operation of this Bill. How does it propose to do this? We find this proposition in the economic statement:

The Government has reviewed the conditions applying to the grant of disability and war widows' pensions having regard to certain decisions by the High Court and their implications for the Repatriation Commission.
These decisions, particularly a decision made this year, mean that such pensions may have to be granted even where there is no evidence whatsoever linking disabilities or death to war service.
I reiterate that-
. . . mean that such pensions may have to be granted even where there is no evidence whatsoever linking disabilities or death to war service.

That is what the Government said in that document. I turn now to page 5 of the High Court judgment. I emphasise that this is not the Solicitor-General's opinion, it is the High Court judgment. I hope that the Minister will not serve me up some half-baked notion from some lawyer when we have a court system which actually makes determinations about what Acts mean. The judgment says:

We have explained that the first of two basic questions put in issue by the parties in the AAT hearing was whether the respondent's anxiety neurosis had arisen out of or was attributable to his war service.
That was the question. Was the anxiety neurosis related to, did it arise out of or was it attributable to his war service? The judgment continues:

The fifth finding of the AAT determined this question in favour of the Commission. With all respect and despite the valiant advocacy of the Solicitor-General, we consider it to be a surprising conclusion. In opinion, it flies in the face of commonsense to say that an anxiety neurosis which is occasioned by reason of the separation of the respondent from his wife because of his war service at a time when she is in desperate need of his company, is not attributable to that war service. It is even more surprising when tested by the onus of proof provision.

In other words, the proposition is put very clearly by the High Court judges that it flies in the face of common sense to suggest this. But, no, the Government is not deterred by that. Not only does the Government not think that it flies in the face of common sense, but it is quite happy to make the proposition in the pieces of paper that are floating around and in the explanatory memorandum that there is no connection between the two facts when the High Court has quite specifically said that there is a connection.

If one continues to read the High Court judgment, one finds that there are a variety of propositions in the majority judgment that go to the very heart of the matter that we are considering in section 47. That is the section that this Government has promised time and again not to alter, amend or change. That promise has been made to veterans' conferences, it has been made in letters to people who are concerned about it and it has been made in this chamber. That is now to be totally ignored. The other propositions in the High Court judgment are also extremely impor- tant. I acknowledge that it is a majority judgment-if the Minister is interested in that fact-and undoubtedly we will have quoted to us the various sections from the dissenting judgment.

TALK.START.PARA: —From the Liberals, you mean.

—No, not from the Liberals. In fact, in this whole exercise the Liberals are seeking to have two bob each way. The veterans and the Returned Services League, under the name of Sir William Keys, have made it very clear what they want to do. They want the type of consultation that this Government promised them. They want that and they want it now. Not only do they not want the Opposition amendments, they want the Bill put aside to allow the type of consultation that the Government promised. If this Opposition was in tune with the veterans' wishes it would be doing just that. It is a pity that Senator Collard has been in this shadow portfolio for such a short time. Otherwise he would have argued much more strongly in the shadow Cabinet and he would have persuaded those people whom he says could not be persuaded because he would have known what was going on, he would have known the history of this operation and he would have known how central the whole matter is to what the veterans have been saying time and time again.

SPEECH.PARA: The National President of the RSL, Sir William Keys, has given us his opinion of the economic statement. Honourable senators should remember that this Bill introduces a change to the legislation-a massive change to something that the Government promised never to change. I take issue with the way in which this change has been made. When we had the Fraser Government's razor gang cuts, the amalgamation proposals of tertiary institutions were introduced in an economic statement. The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) when in opposition in this chamber attacked the Government on that issue. In the same way I attack this Government for introducing a major change in repatriation in a cutting document, in a document that is aimed at saving money. That is what this operation is all about. It is about saving money from groups in the community who cannot afford it-groups who the Government promised would never be subjected to this operation.

The history of this operation is very interesting. Section 47 has been called the Evatt amendment, with very good reason. It is the type of amendment that Dr Evatt, when he was a member of the other place, was working on time and again-immediately after the Second World War until the Labor Government lost power in 1949.

Growth in Outlays

The growth in outlays was one of the most significant aspects of the Howard period. The re-ordering of priorities requires discipline, intelligence and application. Such characteristics were rarely exhibited. In the latter years outlays developed a dangerous momentum reflected in an increasing rate of growth both in real terms and as a proportion of GDP. Moreover, their structure became increasingly distorted-first by the falsehood of turning what should have been direct expenditures into tax expenditures (health and welfare especially) to mask outlays growth: second by expenditure on clearly pork-barrel items; and finally, by the mushrooming of unemployment benefits as the economy began its terrible collapse in 1981-82.

The growth in the structure of outlays itself-culminating in the horrendous $9.6b prospective deficit for 1983-84-imposed huge limitations on the Hawke Government's budgeting. Simply to turn the direction of outlays around, let alone restrain their rate of growth, has meant some sacrifice of higher goals and sheer hard work. Moreover, the rate of growth has been turned around sharply, growth between 1982-83 and 1983-84 was two thirds lower than growth between 1981-82 and 1982-83. (As well, the Hawke Government's responsible action in turning tax expenditures into accountable real outlays added 1.1 per cent to outlays in 1983-84, and should be discounted from the outlays growth in 83-84.)

What these indicators collectively reveal is that Mr Howard, in alliance with Mr Fraser, brought the Australian economy to the point where inflation was out of control, unemployment was continuously and rapidly rising and the potential deficit for 1983-84 was $9.6 billion dollars.

Of course, the future management of our economy is crucial for the continued well-being of all Australians. It is therefore absolutely critical to the future success of our economy that economic policy should never again be committed into the hands of a person whose record is one of obvious ineptitude, widespread policy reverses, and failure on key issues as well as weakness in the face of hostility from vested interests within the coalition partners and from his own backbench. The document I prepared proved these propositions.

Put simply the work of economic recovery that was so ably set in train by the Hawke Government cannot be allowed to be absorbed by those whose records should disqualify them from serious consideration for the national task of efficiently and effectively governing Australia.

In support of this, in the report which is the subject of the honourable senator's questions I argued that it was high time that the appalling management of our predecessors was fully exposed so that the Australian people could see for themselves that the record of Mr Howard and his cohorts cannot stand scrutiny.
There was a real danger, in the unlikely event that the coalition parties might win the next election, Mr Howard would one again be able to wreak his own personal havoc on the Australian economy.
On 21 March 1983 Mr Peacock stated that Mr Howard could be handicapped in the immediate future by having to defend the economic policies of the Fraser Government. That statement remains very true.

The document which is the subject of the honourable senator's question indicated that all of the accepted, major measures of performance prove that the seven years of the former Government, with Mr Howard and Mr Lynch as Treasurers, were an economic disaster. Ultimately, their major strategy of 'fight inflation first' failed because it was the only policy they had. Perhaps it should have been 'fight inflation only'. Sound economic management is more complicated than this. However the final three years were especially tragic because they culminated in the almost total collapse of the Australian economy in 1982. In part, this was caused by the phoney 'resources boom' constructed to aid the winning of the 1980 election campaign.
Economically those years can best be explained by looking at them as three distinct policy periods.

The first policy period, roughly between 1976 and 1978/79, showed a smidgeon of progress in achievement of the goal of lowered inflation (though only in national terms, because Australia's inflation rate remained persistently above that of our international trading partners). Yet the cost of this was the continuing growth in unemployment-which climbed inexorably-since the economy grew only 'in fits and starts', and at a less than satisfactory average rate. Such poor performance was sometimes explained as the necessary concomitant of industrial rationalisation, but of course the reality was steady stagnation rather than rationalisation.

Monetary growth projections were introduced in 1976, and these it must be conceded, achieved 'success' for a couple of years. Nevertheless, the end result of such monetarist policies was a severe and sustained credit squeeze, which forced up interest rates and made real investment unattractive.

The document I prepared and which is the subject of the honourable senator's question went on to point out that in 1979/80, however, the former Government changed direction, and started talking up the 'resources boom'. This talk went on for a couple of years. Of course in some respects this attitude changed economic policies and performance. The monetary targets were overtaken and inflation rose. At the same time, there occurred two bursts of reasonable growth (with a flat spot in 1980), which culminated in a marginal cut in the rate of unemployment in 1980/81 (though this rate was still well above that of 1975/76). But more alarmingly, interest rates began accelerating, and wage and profit expectations were talked up unrealistically. To make matters worse, the former government abandoned all vestiges of a wages policy in 1981.

Finally, after that mis-adventure, came the collapse of 1981-82 and 1982-83. That collapse can be attributed to a combination of the ill effects of the two earlier approaches. The first made people cynical about Australia's real prospects at the same time as it generated little real change in industrial arrangements. The second created inflationary expectations which ended any possibility of firmly based growth.

Abandonment of the attempt to make a wages policy further exacerbated inflation, particularly in the labour market, notwithstanding the nominal efforts at restraining real unit labour costs which had been made. Not surprisingly, industries started to shed labour at an alarming rate, thousands of jobs were lost every month, and the economy shrank. At the end of this period, the Australian economy was in utter disarray. The former government had worked itself into a corner, without policy ideas and with no hope of responding to the situation it had created.

In any debate about the Hawke Government's economic management, and this was the point behind the document which is the subject of the honourable senator's questions, it is crucial to emphasise that the economic recovery has not been, as alleged by the Opposition, some matter of luck. It has resulted from carefully putting policies into place which have achieved the following:
Reduced inflation
Stabilised incomes
Created jobs
Stimulated depressed sectors of the economy, and
Most significantly, encouraged confidence by engendering certainty and a sense of direction.

The former Treasurer, Mr John Howard, has been the keenest and most strident complainant about the Hawke Government's performance in these matters and it seems that he wishes us to forget or ignore his own record in office.

I made the point in the document which is the subject of the honourable senator's question that it is worth remembering, therefore, how economic policy was made under the Fraser Government, because this throws startling light on Mr Howard's claims to expertise and his desire to be taken seriously as an economic manager. The high profile Mr Howard has adopted in Opposition has resulted in him being seen as the economic brains of the Coalition and in him continually being questioned about his leadership ambitions. It is interesting to note that he has refused to pledge his loyalty to his leader.
The high profile, however, would seem to be one way of masking a record of blunders, admissions of mistakes and losses in Cabinet.

Ultimately the question had to be asked whether Mr Howard was ever intellectually strong enough to perform effectively his major role as Treasurer. Was he in fact the puppet of a cabal of Ministers most of whom have now left the political scene? Would he be able to perform any better in any future coalition government? Would we be back on the same old inflation/unemployment/no growth/merry-go-round from which the Hawke Government rescued the nation?

Fortunately it is likely that the Australian people will never know the answers to these questions. If the document I prepared which is the subject of the honourable senator's question, assisted in this debate and the resolution of these issues, then it served its purpose very well.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 26 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Did Energy Systems International Pty Ltd make an application in 1983 to the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council (NERDDC) for a $1m research grant for the purpose of establishing a wind farm at Marrawah in Northern Tasmania; if so: (a) has the application been considered, and if so, with what result; and (b) what were the reasons for NERDDC decision, or for the delay if no decision has been made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. (a) The Project application was received and assessed by NERDDC in 1983. NERDDC did not recommend that the project be supported. (b) NERDDC's advice was as follows:

'The project was not supported by NERDDC, principally because of the lack of support from the Hydro-Electric Commission. The project did not originate with the HEC, nor was it prepared in consultation with that organisation. At the time of submission, it had not received the official approval of the Commission.

As grid-connection is an essential part of the project, it could not proceed without permission from the HEC to connect the wind-farm into the Tasmanian electricity grid. Furthermore, commercial wind farms will not be feasible in Tasmania without the approval of the HEC, as they require both grid-connection and an acceptable electricity purchase price.

Other factors influencing NERDDC's assessment relate to a detailed information relating to the feasibility of wind farms in the Tasmanian context. NERDDC is not convinced that medium-scale wind generators are an entirely appropriate form of electricity generation for Tasmania:
There is a need for a more detailed study of the economic feasibility of wind farms in Tasmania
No detailed study has yet been undertaken of the effects of wind farms on electricity supply in the Tasmanian grid

It is not clear that medium scale wind generators are the most appropriate option. It could be possible that larger, megawatt-scale wind generators, for example, will prove superior in the given application, although it is by no means certain that any wind technology would be competitive with existing power generation systems.

The wind resource data on which the application is based are limited both in duration and in spatial coverage. More extensive data are needed before a major project could be embarked upon with confidence. As a case in point, a 55 kW 'Windmatic' wind generator was installed at Ballarat in 1983, following an 18 month wind resource monitoring period, and immediately suffered two months of unanticipated calm weather.

It is questionable that the project is an entirely appropriate activity for NERDDC, as this demonstration of commercially available wind generators has at least some elements of promoting the concept and familiarising local industry with the technology.

NERDDC holds the view that, before a major demonstration project is carried out in this area, there would be merit in conducting a thorough study on the technical and economic feasibility of wind farms in Tasmania.'

Noting the deficiencies in the application outlined above and NERDDC's view, my predecessor Senator Walsh approved a recommendation that the HEC undertake a technical and economic feasibility study on wind power in Tasmania. The study, which is receiving support under the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Program, is being undertaken in two phases:
Phase I of the study covers wind resources, plant availability, site selection, local manufacture, economics and environmental considerations
Phase II will involve a detailed design study for a particular site and will give consideration to the effect of integrating wind turbines into the grid system.

Work is progressing satisfactorily and wind measuring equipment is now operating at four sites. Analysis of wind data has also commenced with a view to modelling the operation of the system. A report covering Phase I of the study is in the final stages of preparation and will be made available to the public under the normal system for NERD& Program reports-i.e. it will be supplied at the cost of reproduction on application to my Department.

Additionally moves were made to strengthen NERDDC expertise on wind energy matters. In April 1984 Senator Walsh appointed Dr J. D. Kalma of CSIRO, who is an expert on wind energy resources, to the Technical Standing Committee on NERDDC responsible for providing advice on such matters.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 16 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Federal Government developed a drought plan in light of deteriorating seasonal conditions around Australia affecting a larger number of primary producers; if so, what are the details of the arrangement; if not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: In the light of the recent major drought, the Minister for Primary Industry proposed the establishment of a body to review existing drought policy and to recommend alternative policy options.

At the August 1983 meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council, the Council endorsed the establishment of a National Drought Consultative Committee (NDCC) for this purpose. The Committee comprises representatives of Commonwealth Departments of Primary Industry and Finance, State and Northern Territory Departments responsible for agriculture and the National Farmers' Federation.

The NDCC held its inaugural meeting in March 1984 and identified areas which required further examination by the Committee. It met again on 22-23 November 1984 to consider proposals for future drought policy.
The development of NDCC views on a drought policy package was in the context that prime responsibility rested with farmers to take steps to protect themselves from the adverse effects of drought.
The NDCC agreed that drought policy should be based on the attainment of national objectives. Appropriate national objectives were considered to be
- to encourage the efficient allocation of national, regional and farm resources; and
- to minimise the economic hardship to individuals resulting from drought.
Specific national objectives of drought policy were considered to be
- maintenance of land resource;
- maintenance of breeding herds at a level which would enable post drought recovery of livestock industries within a reasonable period;
- enabling post drought sowing of crops and pasture;
- maintenance of minimal living standards for farmers assessed as viable in the long term;
- short term income support for farmers assessed as non-viable in the longer term;
- minimisation of stock distress.
The NDCC considered that drought policy measures should
- be predictable, practicable and cost effective and be consistent with other Government policies;
- encourage adoption by producers of drought mitigation strategies;
- be equitable in their availability to individuals in like economic circumstances, irrespective of industry or region;
- minimise distortions in input and product prices, thereby promoting resource use efficiency;
- minimise inconsistencies between the interests of individuals and society in resource management use; in particular, in land degradation and national herd/ flock size.

On the basis of these objectives, the NDCC agreed that a national drought policy should comprise Commonwealth and State/Northern Territory (NT) measures as follows Commonwealth/States and Northern Territory
- concessional loans under the National Disaster Relief Arrangements;
- freight rebates for transport of livestock, fodder and water;
- soil conservation programs;
- other measures agreed from time to time.
Commonwealth
- taxation related measures;
- Income Equalisation Deposits Scheme;
- household support and rehabilitation assistance under the Rural Adjustment Scheme.
State
- development and provision of information.
In addition, the NDCC supported a reference to the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) on crop and rainfall insurance.

The NDCC agreed to establish a working party to examine the principles which have application to drought declaration. The working party was established in recognition of the desirability of introducing uniformity and the maximum degree of objectivity into the drought declaration/revocation process.
The Government has considered the NDCC report and endorsed the drought policy package agreed by it. A reference has also been sent to the IAC on crop and rainfall insurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 April 1985 (Hansard, page 1136-37) Senator Vigor asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade, a question concerning possible action that the Government could take to defend Australia's interests should a trade war develop as a result of proposals from the United States Congress to impose a surcharge on imports into the US. The Minister for Trade has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is closely monitoring developments and the implication of the proposals before the US Congress to impose a surcharge on US imports. The imposition of such a surcharge would almost certainly precipitate retaliatory action by others.

As a relatively small trading country and exporter of a substantial proportion of most of its agricultural and mineral products, Australia has a vital interest in the effective functioning of an open and predictable multilateral trading system.

There is little doubt that Australia would again be amongst the most affected countries if there was a repeat of the disastrous beggar-thy-neighbour trade policies adopted by governments in the 1930s.

It is for these reasons that we have viewed with concern the growing protectionist pressures in the US and some possible responses to these pressures now before the US Congress. Our concerns have been firmly registered with key US Administration officials on a continuing basis both by Australian Embassy officials in Washington and during a number of recent visits by Australian Ministers and senior officials.

We are encouraged by the responses we have received and recent statements by the Reagan Administration reaffirming their commitment to an open multilateral trading system and their continued strong rejection of any import surcharge proposals.

In addition the US Administration is aware of the implications for an early new round of multilateral trade negotiations of the implementation of an import surcharge, no matter how limited. We are encouraged that the growing momentum towards the launching of a new round should help to counter rising protectionist pressures in the USA and elsewhere.

ANSWER.PARA: The current market value of assets is taken into account under the assets test. Consequently, if the market value of a pensioner's asset or assets is reduced, for whatever reason, that lower value will be assessed in determining the rate of pension payable.

It is open to a pensioner to seek a review of his or her entitlement at any time. In this situation any increase in pension payable because of the reduced value of assets is paid with effect from the first pension pay-day after the pensioner's request for a review of entitlement.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, upon notice, on 16 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do the 1981 census figures reveal that some 76,000 people listed their religious affiliation as Moslem, while some 62,000 stated it as Jewish.
(2) Which Jewish holidays are recognised by the Australian Government as being days which should be regarded as public holidays for members of the Jewish faith in Australia.
(3) Which Islamic holidays, holy days or days of special religious significance are similarly recognised.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The religious denomination of 62,126 people is described in the 1981 census papers as Hebrew; and that of 76,792 people is described as Muslim.

(2) and (3) The Commonwealth Government has no role in determining days which shall be public holidays except in relation to the Australian Public Service, the Australian Capital Territory and the external Territories.

In relation to the APS the Public Service Board has determined that certain days each year are to be observed as public holidays. These are 1 January, 26 January, Good Friday and the following Saturday and Monday, 25 April, the anniversary of the birthday of the Sovereign, Christmas Day and the following day, and any day which in accordance with the law of a State or Territory is to be observed in lieu of any of these days.
This provision enables staff in the APS to observe as holidays those days observed in the community in general. All staff, irrespective of belief, are entitled to a holiday on such occasions.

It is considered reasonable that any staff who, because of their belief, wish to take leave to observe some other day or days in excess of those made generally available, should make their own leave arrangements accordingly. Several leave provisions exist for staff of the APS to meet such specific needs and, subject to departmental convenience, staff may be granted recreation leave or leave without pay to observe a particular feast or holy day.
The widespread introduction of flexible working hours in the APS provides further scope for staff to combine their official duties with their various private commitments.

In relation to the ACT, the Holidays Ordinance 1958 provides that the same days specified above for the APS shall be public holidays, with the addition of Canberra Day in March and Labour Day in October. There is also a provision that the Minister may declare any other day or part of it to be a public holiday in the ACT or in part of it. This provision has very rarely been used and does not allow the Minister to declare holidays specifically for members of particular faiths.

The people whose religious denominations are described in the 1981 Census papers as Hebrew or Muslim do not include people in the external Territories. However, the Public Holiday Ordinances of Christmas and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands provide for the Muslim festival day of Hari Raya Puasa to be a public holiday. The Christmas Island ordinance also provides for there to be public holidays on the Muslim festival day of Hari Raya Haji and on the day of the Chinese New Year and the day following it. Other public holidays in both Territories include 1 January, 26 January, Good Friday, 25 April, the anniversary of the birthday of the Sovereign and Christmas Day and the day following it. These, and the Muslim festival days, are all holidays for the entire communities, not for members of any particular faith. The ordinances of both Territories provide for the Administrators to declare up to two other days each year to be public holidays.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 17 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of a study by two senior researchers at the University of British Columbia in Canada which reveals that spa baths have the potential to carry a multitude of disease carrying and sometimes potentially fatal, microbes, and which indicates that among the threats included are deadly Legionnaires' disease, striptococci, vaginal complaints, rashes, flu-like symptoms, diarrhoea, headaches and backaches.
(2) Is there any evidence of disease linked with spa baths in Australia.
(3) What measures are in place to protect members of the public against possible risks from spa baths.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware that pathogenic organisms can be transmitted through the use of spa baths. The work mentioned by the honourable senator was published in the Canadian Journal of Public Health Vol. 75, 1984, pages 223-226 and suggests that many pathogenic organisms can exist in spas. However the only pathogens which have actually been shown to causes disease as a consequence of spa use are Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Legionella pneumophila.
(2) Pseudomonas aeruginosa skin infection has been reported in health spa whirlpool users from two resorts in the Snowy Mountains area near Jindabyne, New South Wales.

(3) My Department has no authority to introduce measures which might regulate the use of spa pools, this being the responsibility of State/Territory and municipal health authorities. Some State/Territory Health Departments have been investigating semi-private spas and related facilities such as whirlpools to ascertain the presence of disease causing organisms. However there appears to be insufficient Australian information at present to enable the States/Territories to regulate or control the use of these spas/whirlpools. Measures which have been undertaken overseas to reduce health risks associated with these facilities include:
a requirement that users shower prior to using spa facilities
design and maintenance of spas e.g. exclusion of wooden fittings which have a high disinfectant demand
testing and control of disinfection measures
regular cleaning of surfaces and surrounds of spas.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many employees in various Commonwealth Departments are suffering repetitive strain injury.
(2) What steps are being taken by the Government to address this problem.
(3) Will the Prime Minister consider referring the matter of RSI to the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission for further consideration and recommendations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A census conducted by the Public Service Board has indicated that at 31 December 1984 there were 3,029 sufferers of RSI in departments and statutory authorities staffed under the Public Service Act.

(2) On 11 October 1984 Mr Dawkins, as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, announced the formation of a Task Force on RSI in the Australian Public Service. The Task Force, with representation from unions and relevant departments and statutory authorities, is to report to the Government in June this year on all steps required to cope with the problem.

(3) At its first meeting, on 30 October 1984, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission established an ad hoc committee on RSI which is to report in mid 1985 on elements of an appropriate national strategy to deal with the problem.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Thursday 16 May 1985 (Hansard, page 2069) Senator MacGibbon asked me a question concerning the use of Boeing 707s for in-flight refuelling. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) has provided the following answer:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is aware that there are strategic circumstances in which an in-flight refuelling capability would be important, but we could expect substantial warning of such situations.

It was this Government which in 1983 decided to acquire two additional Boeing 707 aircraft with a view to their potential for later conversion to in-flight refuelling if circumstances were to warrant that further investment.

The conversion of the Boeing 707s to tankers could be undertaken relatively quickly if strategic circumstances were to alter in such a way as to give priority to increasing the FA18's already substantial range, noting that the aircraft is particularly suited to operating from airfields to be located strategically around northern Australia-Learmonth, Derby, Darwin and Tindal.
The level of priority to be assigned this development is a matter on which we expect advice from the Dibb Review.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday, 21 May, (Hansard, page 2213) Senator Sir John Carrick asked me a question about anti-ballistic missile research by the Soviet Union. On 22 May (Hansard, page 2336) I gave him a supplementary answer to my initial answer. I now have further information to provide as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government regards the existing agreements between the United States and the Soviet Union as important to all countries, because the interests of all are engaged. It attached great importance to full compliance by both parties with all their agreements.
